Course ID: IWME_V 502, Course Title: Engineering Hydrology, Course Description: Water cycle and role of water in the environment and environmental engineering. Physical and statistical prediction methods for design related to hydrologic systems; precipitation; evaporation; snow hydrology; infiltration and base flow; surface runoff; channel and storage routing; unit hydrograph methods. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: IWME_V 503, Course Title: Chemical and Biological Industrial Water Treatment Design, Course Description: Fundamental principles of process design for chemical and biological systems to treat water used in and effluents generated from industrial processes. Industry application examples: mining, oil sands, oil and gas, pulp and paper, agriculture, food and beverage. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: JAPN_V 320, Course Title: Intermediate Japanese I A, Course Description: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 320 or JAPN 210 or JAPN 360. Recommended pre-requisites: one of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: JAPN_V 360, Course Title: Intensive Intermediate Japanese I, Course Description: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Offered in Term 1. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 360 or JAPN 212 or both JAPN 210, JAPN 211 or both JAPN 320, JAPN 321. Recommended pre-requisites: one of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: KIN_V 342, Course Title: Creating Effective, Developmentally Appropriate, Physical Activity Learning Environments, Course Description: The pedagogical skills and knowledge required to design, and implement, developmentally appropriate physical activities learning environments in a variety of settings. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of KIN 140., Credits: 	3

Course ID: KIN_V 355, Course Title: Movement Experiences for Young Children, Course Description: The design and implementation of movement experiences for children in early childhood years. [3-0] Prerequisite: All of KIN 110, KIN 131, KIN 140, KIN 150, KIN 160, KIN 211., Credits: 	3

Course ID: KIN_V 453, Course Title: Understanding and Changing Physical Activity Behaviour, Course Description: Examining the influence of psychological factors across different settings and populations, with a particular focus on interventions aimed at enhancing mental health. Understanding psychology can be used to design effective interventions at the individual and community level. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: KIN 150., Credits: 	3

Course ID: KIN_V 464, Course Title: Health Promotion and Physical Activity, Course Description: Current perspectives on health promotion and health education; design and implementation of health promotion strategies in a variety of arenas, particularly health promotion/education strategies aimed at encouraging physical activity. [3-0] Prerequisite: All of KIN 150, KIN 160, KIN 205, KIN 262., Credits: 	3

Course ID: KIN_V 570, Course Title: Research Methods in Kinesiology, Course Description: Research methods applied to the study of sport and physical activity, the nature of scientific inquiry, the design of experiments, the survey as a research medium, the historical and philosophical methods of inquiry, the writing of the research report. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: KIN_V 585, Course Title: Performance Planning, Course Description: Application of findings from sport profile and gap analysis to the planning and design of high performance training and coaching programs. Focuses on quadrennial, annual, meso and microcycle planning to integrate key factors that impact athlete performance and progression along the athlete development pathway. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: KIN_V 586, Course Title: Coaching Effectiveness, Course Description: Analysis of athlete performance and appropriate design and application of coaching intervention and skill acquisition for athlete and coach development. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: KORN_V 415, Course Title: Korean Conversation and Composition, Course Description: Structured conversation practice and weekly composition assignments based on viewing one designated Korean television program per week. Recommended pre-requisite: KORN 300., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: LFS_V 450, Course Title: Land, Food, and Community III: Leadership in Campus Food System Sustainability, Course Description: Design, analysis, recommendation or implementation of solutions in response to a food sustainability issue faced by community partners. Emphasis is on professional communication, leadership development, project management and decision-making skills., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LARC_V 421, Course Title: Creativity and Design Applied, Course Description: An exploration of creativity and design and their application to a number of design disciplines. Web based. [3-0-0], Credits: 	3

Course ID: LARC_V 515, Course Title: Planting Design, Course Description: Functional, ecological, and behavioural theory and practice applied to planting design at different scales. Prerequisite: LARC 316. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LARC_V 523, Course Title: Landscape Architecture Theory, Course Description: Theoretical positions in landscape architecture and their relation to designed landscapes. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LARC_V 525, Course Title: Design Research Methods, Course Description: Examination of various design research methods in contemporary practice in landscape architecture. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LARC_V 531, Course Title: Landscape Technologies I, Course Description: Terrain design, drainage and stormwater management. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 531 or LARC 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LARC_V 540, Course Title: Site Analysis and Planning, Course Description: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing stormwater management design. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 540, LARC 440 or DES 231. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LARC_V 542, Course Title: Aesthetics and Sustainability, Course Description: Analysis and planning of landscapes to communicate sustainability and to inform public awareness and design by exploring the relationship between aesthetics and sustainability. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LARC_V 595, Course Title: Graduate Project Part I, Course Description: Preparation of a graduation design project proposal including literature review. Prerequisite: LARC 525. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LLED_V 210, Course Title: Introduction to Analyzing Meanings of Images in Texts, Course Description: Systematic analysis of visual and verbal modalities in academic and professional registers through a grammar designed for this purpose., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LLED_V 469, Course Title: Inquiry-Based Pedagogy in School Library Programs, Course Description: Principles and practices of teachers and teacher-librarians designing and teaching curriculum using inquiry-based pedagogy. LLED 469 is a core course for the Teacher Librarian Diploma., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LLED_V 527, Course Title: MATERIALS DEVELOPMENT FOR INDIGENOUS LANGUAGE LEARNING & TEACHING, Course Description: Conceptual understanding and practical experience in designing and developing language print materials and interactive multimedia. Overview of production, publication, dissemination, and accessibility of language resources, and pedagogical approaches for language revitalization and education efforts using multimodal resources. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 344, Course Title: Innovation, Law, and Regulation, Course Description: Examines and applies interdisciplinary research on regulation, governance, and institutional and legal design under conditions of change and uncertainty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 403, Course Title: Principles of Sentencing, Course Description: This course is designed to teach students the law and policy involved in sentencing persons convicted of crimes. Students will develop an in-depth understanding of statutory and case law rules regarding sentencing and will be required to apply those rules to actual sentencing scenarios. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 422, Course Title: Intellectual Property, Course Description: Copyright, patents, trademarks, industrial design, the protection of computer software, and torts such as passing-off and breach of confidence. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 422 or LAW 570. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 570, Course Title: Intellectual Property, Course Description: Copyright, patents, trade marks, industrial design, the protection of computer software, and torts such as passing-off and breach of confidence. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 570 or LAW 422. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LING_V 333, Course Title: Research Methods for Linguistics, Course Description: Research methods used in linguistics and speech science. Emphasis on scientific reasoning, critical thinking, experimental design, and the ethics and methods of linguistic data-collection. Prerequisite: All of LING 200, LING 201., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MANU_V 201, Course Title: Technical Communication, Course Description: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Manufacturing Engineering Program. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150. Equivalency: APSC 201 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MANU_V 330, Course Title: Manufacturing Engineering Project I, Course Description: Project-based, multi-step manufacturing engineering design and problem solving. [1-4-0; 1-4-0] Prerequisite: MANU 230. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MANU_V 378, Course Title: Engineering Materials II, Course Description: Materials selection for different design criteria; importance of shape and processing variables; computer software in selection. Credit will be granted for only one of MTRL 280 or MANU 378. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: APSC 278. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MANU_V 380, Course Title: Manufacturing Processes I, Course Description: Correlation between material properties and processibility for practical engineering manufacturing routes. Calculations and design. Application of heat/mass/fluid transport, mechanics and thermodynamics to manufacturing processes. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: All of APSC 278, APSC 279, MTRL 264, MECH 260 and one of MANU 261, MTRL 250 and one of MECH 280, MTRL 263. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MANU_V 430, Course Title: Manufacturing Design Capstone Project, Course Description: Project-based, multi-step, multi-part Capstone design project involving manufacturing engineering design methods, problem solving. [1-4-0; 1-4-0] Prerequisite: MANU 330. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MANU_V 453, Course Title: Additive Manufacturing Design, Course Description: Design tools and methods for additive manufacturing, complex digital geometry creation, computer aided design tools, additive manufacturing workflow development, producibility analysis, analysis of 3D data sets for suitability to additive manufacturing processes. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing or greater. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MANU_V 480, Course Title: Manufacturing Processes II, Course Description: Numerical modelling of manufacturing processes, linkage between material, process, properties and product geometry, heat/mass transport, thermodynamics and design principles applied to practical engineering processes. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: MANU 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MRNE_V 400, Course Title: Directed Studies, Course Description: A research project approved by the supervisor in the field of interest of the student designed to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Note: the supervisor may be teaching at the Marine Centre; or a member of faculty of WCUMSS whether at the Marine Centre as a research investigator or as one of the members of WCUMSS., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: MTRL_V 201, Course Title: Technical Communication, Course Description: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Materials Engineering Program. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150. Corequisite: MTRL 280. Equivalency: APSC201 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 280, Course Title: Materials in Design, Course Description: The process of materials selection for different design criteria; the importance of shape and processing variables; the use of computer software in the selection process. [2-0-3] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 361, Course Title: Modelling of Materials Processes, Course Description: Mathematical and physical modelling of processes employed in the production of materials. The application of models to analyze, design and improve materials production. [3-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: MTRL_V 460, Course Title: Monitoring and Optimization of Materials Processing, Course Description: Measurement systems for materials processing and evaluation, methods of data collection and analysis in materials engineering, materials processing monitoring and control, design of experiments for materials processing and optimization. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 466, Course Title: Engineering Project I, Course Description: Design projects to illustrate the full spectrum of design encountered in Metals and Materials Engineering including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials. [1-0-5] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 467, Course Title: Engineering Project II, Course Description: Design projects to illustrate the full spectrum of design encountered in Metals and Materials Engineering including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials. [1-0-5] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 472, Course Title: Welding and Joining of Materials, Course Description: Case studies addressing temperature modelling in welding and joining, material selection for welds and joints, calculation of properties for welds and joints, mechanical analysis of joints, and design of welding and joining procedures. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 475, Course Title: Microstructure Engineering, Course Description: Follows the production of metallurgical products, focusing on process design models used to describe solidification, recrystallization, and precipitation. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 478, Course Title: Electronic Materials, Course Description: Semiconductor materials, MOSFET structure, operation and applications in digital circuits, fabrication techniques, basic mask and fabrication flow design and semiconductor fabrication process theories at an entry level. [3-0-0], Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 484, Course Title: Materials for Aerostructures and Engines, Course Description: Engineering theory of aerospace structural material mix: metal alloys, ceramics, and polymer composites. Material requirements for weight-, damage tolerant-, cost efficient-design. Overview of material characterization, including fracture and fatigue. Statistical variability, material allowables, structural certification. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 494, Course Title: Composite Materials, Course Description: Understanding the properties and the mechanical behaviour of composite materials with emphasis on analysis, design, and manufacturing. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 495, Course Title: Biomaterials, Course Description: Engineered materials in medical applications with an emphasis on material properties, functionality, design, and material response in the biological environment. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 496, Course Title: Materials Sustainability, Course Description: Concepts of life cycle analysis, circular economy and critical materials. Project-based introduction to key concepts, calculations, and design. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 517, Course Title: Case Studies in Advanced Materials Manufacturing, Course Description: The full spectrum of design encountered including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 558, Course Title: Corrosion, Course Description: Modern theories relating to corrosion and corrosion protection of metals. Thermodynamic and kinetic phenomena, corrosion measurements, inhibition and passivation, design for corrosive environments, stress corrosion cracking theory. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 564, Course Title: Hydrometallurgical Reactor Design and Analysis, Course Description: Batch leaching kinetics, leaching mechanisms; statistical methods for design of multiparticle continuous leaching reactors; coupled heat and mass balances, mixing phenomena, redox and precipitation reactions, complex mineralogical feeds; heap and dump leaching. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 588, Course Title: Electrochemical Science, Engineering and Technology, Course Description: Electrochemical interfaces; electrode reactions; thermodynamics; kinetics and transport processes in electrochemical systems; experimental techniques. Electrochemical reactors and processes; modelling, design and economics. Electrochemical technologies; electrosynthesis, batteries and fuel cells. Electro-metallurgy; electrowinning and refining of metals, corrosion, leaching and cementation. Equivalency: CHBE577, MMAT588 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 594, Course Title: Advanced Composite Materials, Course Description: Processing and properties of advanced polymer based composite materials with emphasis on analysis, design, and manufacturing. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MTRL_V 595, Course Title: Advanced Biomaterials, Course Description: Formation and structure-function relations of biological materials, the interaction of tissue-synthetic biomaterials, advanced biomaterials design, biomimetic processing, and current progress in drug delivery systems and biomedical devices. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 226, Course Title: Technical Communication for Mechanical Engineers, Course Description: Written and oral communication. Preparation of design reports, business correspondence, verbal, online, and visual presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in the second year of Mechanical Engineering. [1-0-1;1-0-1] Prerequisite: A score of 65% or higher in one of ENGL 112, WRDS 150, APSC 176. Corequisite: All of MECH 220, MECH 221, MECH 222, MECH 223, MECH 224, MECH 225. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 325, Course Title: Machine Design, Course Description: Selection of flexible drives, bearings, fluid power system components, and couplings. Design of shafts, bolted joints and power screws. Design and selection of gears, gear trains, and mechanisms. Recommended co-requisite: MECH 360. [3-0-3] Prerequisite: One of MECH 223, MECH 260. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: MECH_V 328, Course Title: Mechanical Engineering Design Project, Course Description: Applying the design process, making educated assumptions and decisions, and working in teams to provide a new mechanical design. Weekly lecture discussing product development and various factors affecting the design. [1-4-1] Prerequisite: MECH 223. (And third year standing in Mechanical Engineering) This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 329, Course Title: Materials for Mechanical Design, Course Description: Selection of material properties for mechanical design. Metals and alloys, ceramics, polymers, composites and other hybrid materials. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Either (a) MECH 224 or (b) all of APSC 278, MECH 260. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 375, Course Title: Heat Transfer, Course Description: Steady and transient conduction. Radiation heat transfer. Convective heat and mass transfer in pipes and from external surfaces. Design of heat exchangers. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Either (a) MECH 225 or (b) one of CHBE 241, ENPH 257, PHYS 203 and one of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 411, Course Title: Air Pollution, Technology and Society, Course Description: Causes and effects of air pollution in the context of technology and society. Topics include: impact of air pollutants on air quality and climate, atmospheric science, public policy, collective action, environmental justice, science communication, economic externalities, and ethical engineering design. Recommended pre-requisite: third-year standing. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Second-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 412, Course Title: Engineering in Society and Technological Stewardship, Course Description: Societal and environmental aspects of engineering activities, including interactions between engineering and the economic, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society and the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; concepts of socially sustainable design and development; and environmental and technological stewardship. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 421, Course Title: Mechatronics System Instrumentation, Course Description: Architecture of mechatronics devices; integration of mechanical, electronics, sensors, actuators, computer and real time software systems; PLC and PC based systems; discrete and continuous automation system design. [2-2-2] Prerequisite: MECH 366. Corequisite: MECH 420. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: MECH_V 423, Course Title: Mechatronic Product Design, Course Description: Design of mechatronic systems for industrial and human-centric applications; compliant structures; electronic circuits to interface with sensors and actuators; embedded systems; precision timing and control; data acquisition and processing; user interfaces; and product innovation. [2-3-2] Prerequisite: All of MECH 366, ELEC 302, CPEN 312. and 4th year standing. Corequisite: CPEN 333. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: MECH_V 426, Course Title: Mechanical Design, Course Description: Design of shafts and welded joints. Fatigue and fracture considerations in design: failure types, failure under static and dynamic loading, fatigue failure, crack initiation, and propagation. Introduction to the FEM in mechanical design. Students can only receive credit for one of MECH 326 or MECH 426. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: One of MECH 223, MECH 260. Corequisite: MECH 360., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 453, Course Title: Aerospace Capstone Design Project, Course Description: A capstone course to provide students experience in the design/development of practical mechanical and aerospace devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, MECH 490 or APSC 496. [1-2-2; 1-2-2] Prerequisite: All of MECH 327, MECH 328, MECH 360, MECH 426. and fourth-year standing in the Aerospace Option. Equivalency: MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, MECH 490, APSC 496 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MECH_V 454, Course Title: Thermofluids Capstone Design Project, Course Description: A capstone course to provide students experience in the design/development of practical mechanical and thermofluids devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496. [1-2-2; 1-2-2] Prerequisite: All of MECH 325, MECH 327, MECH 328, MECH 360. and fourth-year standing in the Thermofluids Option. Equivalency: MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, MECH 490, APSC 496 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MECH_V 455, Course Title: Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering Capstone Design Project, Course Description: A capstone course to provide students experience in the design/development of practical naval architecture and marine engineering devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496. [1-2-2; 1-2-2] Prerequisite: All of MECH 325, MECH 328, MECH 360, MECH 380. and fourth-year standing in the Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering Option. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MECH_V 456, Course Title: Energy and Environment Capstone Design Project, Course Description: A capstone course to provide students experience in the design/development of practical energy and environment devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496. [1-2-2; 1-2-2] Prerequisite: All of MECH 325, MECH 327, MECH 328, MECH 360. and fourth-year standing in the Energy and Environment Option. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MECH_V 457, Course Title: Flex Capstone Design Project, Course Description: A capstone design project designed to give students experience in the design/development of practical mechanical devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496. [1-2-2; 1-2-2-] Prerequisite: All of MECH 325, MECH 328, MECH 360 and fourth-year standing in Mechanical Engineering. Equivalency: MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, MECH 490, APSC 496. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MECH_V 458, Course Title: Mechatronics Capstone Design Project, Course Description: A capstone design program designed to give students experience in the design/development of practical mechanical and mechatronics devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496. [1-2-2; 1-2-2] Prerequisite: All of MECH 325, MECH 328, MECH 360 and fourth-year standing in the Mechatronics Option. Equivalency: MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, MECH 490, APSC 496. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MECH_V 459, Course Title: Biomedical Biomechanics and Medical Devices Capstone Design Project, Course Description: A capstone design program designed to give students experience in the design and development of practical biomedical devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. For students in the Biomechanics and Medical Devices Option only. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496. [1-2-2; 1-2-2-] Prerequisite: All of MECH 325, MECH 328, MECH 360 and fourth-year standing in the Biomedical Option. Equivalency: MECH453, MECH454, MECH455, MECH456, MECH457, MECH458, MECH459, MECH 490, APSC496. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MECH_V 467, Course Title: Computer Control of Mechatronics Systems, Course Description: Block diagrams and transfer functions, continuous and discrete domain transformations, feedback control system characteristics, control design in both continuous and discrete domain, absolute and relative stability, laboratory examples of Mechatronic systems design. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 467 or MECH 541. Credit cannot be obtained for both MECH 466 and MECH 467. [3-2*-2] Prerequisite: One of MECH 366, MANU 386. Equivalency: MECH541 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: MECH_V 473, Course Title: Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning, Course Description: Principles of air conditioning; psychometrics and refrigeration. Heat transfer through building materials. Estimation of heating and cooling loads including the use of current software. System design. Ground, air and water source heat pumps. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: MECH 375. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 478, Course Title: Internal Combustion Engines, Course Description: Analysis of spark and compression ignition engines. Calculation of fuel economy, power, and emission. Practical and regulatory considerations in engine design. Engine emission and control systems. Recommended pre-requisite: MECH 327. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 478 or MECH 578. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) MECH 225 or (b) one of CHBE 241, ENPH 257 and one of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280. Equivalency: MECH578 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 481, Course Title: Aerodynamics of Aircraft I, Course Description: Analysis of airfoils and wings. Potential flow, thin airfoil theory, lifting line analysis of wings. Predicting viscous drag. Numerical methods for analysis and design of airfoils and wings. Use of wind tunnels for experimental study of aerodynamics. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 481 or MECH 581. [3-1*-0] Prerequisite: [MECH380] Equivalency: MECH581 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 485, Course Title: Aircraft Design: Structures, Course Description: Structural components of aircraft, introduction to the finite element method, bending and buckling of thin plates. Design of aircraft wing and fuselage structures, moments of inertia for complex shapes. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of MECH 224, MECH 260. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 486, Course Title: Introduction to Ship Design, Course Description: This course introduces the ship design process from a Systems Engineering point of view. Topics include ship operational requirements, space and weight estimation, parametric design, optimization techniques, and the impacts of ship design on economics and the environment. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 481 or NAME 581. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) MECH 380 or (b) CIVL 315. Corequisite: All of MECH 488, CIVL 435. Equivalency: NAME581 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 488, Course Title: Introduction to Ship Hydrodynamics, Course Description: Ship terminology, lines plans, ship hydrostatics, transverse and longitudinal stability of ships, dimensional analysis, ship resistance prediction; ship propulsion methods, propeller selection and design. Recommended prerequisites: One of MECH 380 or CIVL 315, or enrollment in the NAME MEng or NAME MEL program. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 489, Course Title: Experimental Thermofluids, Course Description: Experimental uncertainty. Design of experiments. Test facilities. Temperature and pressure measurement techniques and instrumentation. Velocity and flow rate measurement techniques. Flow visualization. Case studies of industrial and research experimental practice. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 489 or MECH 582. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: All of MECH 375, MECH 380. Equivalency: MECH582 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: MECH_V 490, Course Title: Interdisciplinary Capstone, Course Description: Design Project An extension to projects in the New Venture Design Program that introduces additional technical design principles and requirements. Registration for this program is only permitted for Mechanical Engineering students who are in the New Venture Design Program. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 453, MECH 454, MECH 455, MECH 456, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, MECH 490, or APSC 496. [1*-1-1]; [1*-1-1] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 520, Course Title: Control Sensors and Actuators, Course Description: Review of control, instrumentation and design. Performance specification of control components, component matching, error analysis. Operating principles, analysis, modelling, design considerations of control sensors and actuators such as analog sensors for motion measurement, digital transducers, stepper motors, DC motors, induction motors, synchronous motors, and hydraulic actuators. Control techniques pertaining to actuators. Applications. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MECH_V 526, Course Title: Mechatronic System Design Project I, Course Description: The design, analysis, manufacturability, instrumentation and computer control of a selected dynamic machinery assembly will be studied. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: MECH_V 578, Course Title: Internal Combustion Engines, Course Description: Analysis of spark and compression ignition engines. Calculation of fuel economy, power and emission. Practical and regulatory considerations in engine design. Numerical engine modelling and analysis. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 478 or MECH 578. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MEDI_V 503, Course Title: Introduction to Clinical, Patient Oriented and Translational Research, Course Description: Framing appropriate research questions, appropriate research designs, protocol development, key concepts in regulatory approval and human ethical oversight in Canada, privacy and knowledge translation. For students pursuing clinical, patient oriented and translational research. Prerequisite: Permission of Experimental Medicine Program Director This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MICB_V 425, Course Title: Microbial Ecological Genomics, Course Description: Intrinsic and extrinsic forces driving prokaryotic genome evolution. Gene transfer; microbial species concepts; community genome structure, function and dynamics; ecological impacts of microbial genome diversity. Emphasis on problem solving and experimental design. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 335, MICB 325, BIOT 380., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MIDW_V 115, Course Title: Research Methods for Midwives, Course Description: Research designs used in midwifery research, types of studies reported in the midwifery and health care literature, research methodology and basic principles of epidemiology, biostatistics and social research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 200, Course Title: Mineral Resources Engineering I, Course Description: Introduction to the mining life cycle and the design, planning, operation, and closure of mining systems, with a focus on mining methods, mineral processing, community engagement, and social license to operate. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 201, Course Title: Mineral Resources Engineering II, Course Description: The design, planning, and operation, and closure of mining operations, with a focus on mineral processing technologies, plant design, waste and tailings management, and the future of mining. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: MINE 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 291, Course Title: Introduction to Mining, Course Description: Leading practices and technologies employed in the design, planning, and operation of mining systems. Life cycle of surface and underground mining systems. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 302, Course Title: Underground Mining and Design, Course Description: Selection, design, and development of underground mining methods based upon physical, geological, economic, and environmental constraints. Underground excavation methods and equipment selection. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: MINE_V 304, Course Title: Rock Fragmentation, Course Description: Theory and practice of rock fragmentation by drilling and blasting; introduction to explosives and initiation systems; design of surface and underground blasts; machine excavation systems for tunneling and stoping; environmental impacts, safety, and risk assessment. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 310, Course Title: Surface Mining and Design, Course Description: Surface mining methods, calculation of pit limits, cutoff grades, break-even criteria, stripping ratios, ultimate pit depth and dimensions, and pit sequencing. Geotechnical inputs to surface mine design. Loading and hauling equipment, production rates, capacity and systems. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: MINE_V 350, Course Title: Modelling and Simulation, Course Description: Methods for determining the behaviour of large scale industrial systems and their application to the design and analysis of such systems. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: STAT 251. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 395, Course Title: Mineral Deposit Modelling, Course Description: Types of mineral deposits. Exploration and sampling methods. Methods for data analysis and computer modelling of mineral deposits and their use in production planning and design. [2-1-1] Prerequisite: MINE 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 402, Course Title: Mine Ventilation and Occupational Health and Safety, Course Description: Design and analysis for ventilation systems for mining. Topics such as ventilation design, ventilation surveys, thermodynamic aspects, psychrometry of air and air conditioning. [3-2-0] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 403, Course Title: Rock Engineering Design, Course Description: The design of rock slopes and underground openings with respect to stress, structure and the rock mass. Stabilization and monitoring of rock movement. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MINE 303. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 435, Course Title: Plant and Process Design, Course Description: Design of unit operations in a mineral processing plant including crushing, grinding, classification, gravity separation, magnetic separation, flotation, thickening and filtration. Equipment selection and sizing, flowsheet design, circuit analysis and processing options. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: MINE 331. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 436, Course Title: Industrial Mixing, Course Description: Fundamentals of mixing technology, and industrial mixing systems and equipment. Selection, design, monitor, and scale-up mixing systems for mining applications. [2-2-2*] Prerequisite: MATH 255 and one of MECH 280, CIVL 215. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 485, Course Title: Cave Mining Systems: Design and Planning, Course Description: Designs, planning, and leading practices are applied to underground mining systems reliant on induced and controlled rock mass caving. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MINE 303. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 491, Course Title: Mine and Plant Engineering Design Feasibility Study, Course Description: Mining Engineering design project from scope definition to final design and project feasibility. Based on a problem from industry and/or research. [2-2-0; 2-2-0] Prerequisite: All of MINE 302, MINE 303, MINE 310, MINE 331, MINE 333, MINE 350, MINE 396. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: MINE_V 505, Course Title: Advanced Topics in Rock Engineering, Course Description: Rock mass properties and numerical modelling applied to rock engineering design with particular emphasis on applications in rock slopes and tunneling. Permission of the instructor is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 507, Course Title: Block Caving Systems, Course Description: Mass mining (caving) methods, their design and operation, the value proposition and the key value drivers. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 527, Course Title: Simulation and Optimization of Mineral Processes, Course Description: Mineral process simulators including off-line optimization strategies; optimal flow sheet design. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 527 or MINE 576. Prerequisite: One of MINE 526, MINE 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 544, Course Title: Mining Environment Case Studies, Course Description: Regulatory requirements for mine-mill environmental protection in design, operation and closure. Studies of environmental impact statements and closure plans. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 544 or MINE 574. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 551, Course Title: Applied Underground Rock Mechanics, Course Description: Study of design methods; underground engineering of openings, pillars and support. Emphasis on design with input being stress, structure and rock mass, employing analytical, empirical and numerical tools. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MINE_V 589, Course Title: Mine Waste Management Case Studies, Course Description: Case study analysis including design, construction, operations and closure of mine waste facilities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MUSC_V 320, Course Title: Computer Music, Course Description: The study of computer applications to music, focusing on digital synthesis techniques and languages, methods of algorithmic composition, and the design of music editors. Prerequisite: [MUSC319] or permission of instructor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MUSC_V 321, Course Title: Music Appreciation, Twentieth-Century, Course Description: Designed for students with little or no musical background. Not for credit toward the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: NAME_V 501, Course Title: Advanced Ship Structures, Course Description: Pressure hull design; finite element analysis applications; classification rules; ice and ice loads; dynamic loads including slamming, risk and reliability. Prerequisite: CIVL 435. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: NAME_V 502, Course Title: Advanced Ship Hydrodynamics, Course Description: Advanced ship resistance; boundary layers; propeller design; numerical methods in hydrodynamics; advanced marine vehicles; ocean waves; cavitation; ship vibration. Includes a laboratory component involving a wave/towing tank and computational fluid dynamics project. Prerequisite: MECH 488. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: NAME_V 591, Course Title: Computer-Aided Ship Design Project, Course Description: A capstone design project designed to give students experience in the preliminary design of a special purpose ship. Students work individually and in teams, using advanced design software and databases, to design a vessel according to specified criteria. Recommended pre-requisites: All of NAME 581, NAME 578. Recommended co-requisites: All of NAME 502, NAME 522, NAME 501, NAME 566. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: NURS_V 531, Course Title: Theoretical Foundations of Clinical Education, Course Description: Theories of learning and their implications for the design of clinical learning experiences. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: NURS_V 535, Course Title: Design of Clinical Informatics Solutions, Course Description: Fundamental theories, concepts, and processes in the fields of software design in healthcare. Restricted to students in the Graduate Certificate in Clinical Informatics program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: NURS_V 537, Course Title: Data and Databases for Clinical Informatics, Course Description: Database design, interoperability and terminology standards, knowledge representation and management, computerized clinical decision support including artificial intelligence, artificial intelligence bias, machine learning, and information visualization. Introduction to and application of knowledge management strategies in clinical informatics. Restricted to students in the Graduate Certificate in Clinical Informatics program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: OSOT_V 527, Course Title: Becoming an Evidence-Informed Occupational Therapy Practitioner, Course Description: Assumptions and principles of qualitative and quantitative research designs; elements of basic research designs for investigating and evaluating occupational performance and diverse issues relevant to occupational science and occupational therapy are introduced, emphasizing critical appraisal of occupational therapy research literature. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PATH_V 404, Course Title: Diagnostic Histochemistry, Course Description: Theory and practice of common histochemical techniques; experimental design, data analysis and presentation., Credits: 	6

Course ID: PATH_V 452, Course Title: Clerkship in Anatomic Pathology, Course Description: An elective course open to third-year medical students, designed to familiarize the student with Anatomic Pathology, including Surgical Pathology, Pediatric Pathology, Autopsy Pathology and Cytology. This elective may involve attendance at one or more affiliated hospitals. Registration requires consent of the Department and enrolment may be limited., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PATH_V 477, Course Title: Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control, Course Description: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control. Equivalency: SPPH 401, Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHAR_V 205, Course Title: Clinical Epidemiology & Pharmaceutical Outcomes I, Course Description: Population-level study designs and critical appraisal skills in evidence evaluation, with a special emphasis on evidence-based pharmacy practice. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHAR_V 305, Course Title: Clinical Epidemiology & Pharmaceutical Outcomes II, Course Description: Population-level study designs and their critical appraisal skills in evidence evaluation, with a special emphasis on evidence-based pharmacy practice and the practical application of population-level data analysis and interpretation. Prerequisite: PHAR 205. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHAR_V 561, Course Title: Pharmacoepidemiology, Course Description: Principles and applications of pharmacoepidemiology. Practical skills in designing, conducting, and appraising studies of medications in large populations. Prerequisite: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PCTH_V 402, Course Title: Systematic Pharmacology Laboratory, Course Description: A series of demonstrated, group, and individual laboratory experiments designed to illustrate the concepts and hypotheses of pharmacology. The course is restricted to Honours students in Pharmacology, but may be taken by others with permission of the department head. [0-7-0;0-7-0] Prerequisite: All of PCTH 302, PCTH 303., Credits: 	6

Course ID: PCTH_V 451, Course Title: Review of Clinical Pharmacology, Course Description: This course has been designed as a basic science elective for third-year medical students. Prerequisite: Departmental approval required., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PCTH_V 501, Course Title: Structure-Activity Relationships in Pharmacology, Course Description: Lectures, discussions and assigned reading on physicochemical approaches to drug design - the relationship between molecular structure and pharmacological activity in various representative classes of drugs. Given in odd-numbered and alternate years. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PCTH_V 512, Course Title: Experimental Design and Analysis in Pharmacology, Course Description: A series of lectures, tutorials and exercises designed to improve student skills in the design and statistical analyses of pharmacological experiments. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHRM_V 451, Course Title: Critical Appraisal of Pharmacotherapy Literature, Course Description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews, epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	4

Course ID: PHYS_V 319, Course Title: Electronics Laboratory, Course Description: A project-oriented lab introducing the design and construction of microprocessor-controlled devices. [1-4-0] Prerequisite: One of PHYS 209, PHYS 219, ENPH 259., Credits: 	3

Course ID: POLI_V 335, Course Title: Comparative Federalism, Course Description: An empirical and normative analysis of federalism as a way of structuring political life in industrialized democracies, investigating explanations for the design, persistence and operation of federal systems. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: PSYC_V 217, Course Title: Research Methods, Course Description: Focus on various research methods used in psychology, with an emphasis on critical thinking and experimental design. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 217 or PSYC 277. Restricted to students in one of PSYC Major, BA COGS Major. Corequisite: Either(a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PSYC_V 218, Course Title: Analysis of Behavioural Data, Course Description: Use of inferential statistics in psychology and conceptual interpretation of data; experimental design (laboratory, field research methods); presentation of data analyses in reports. Credit will be granted for only one of: PSYC 218, PSYC 278, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, EPSE 482, FRST 231, GEOG 374, KIN 371, POLI 380, SOCI 328, STAT 200, STAT 203. Restricted to students in one of PSYC Major, BA COGS Major. Prerequisite: One of PSYC 217, PSYC 277. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PSYC_V 359, Course Title: Advanced Research Methods in Behavioural Sciences, Course Description: Prepares students for graduate studies or other advanced behavioural research; experimental design and analytic techniques; laboratory with computer applications. Restricted to students with second-year standing or higher and a cumulative average at or above 76%. Prerequisite: One of PSYC 218, PSYC 278., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PSYC_V 408, Course Title: Research in Social Psychology, Course Description: Representative studies on social psychological topics; emphasis on the formulation of significant questions and the design and execution of relevant research. Restricted to students with third-year standing or higher. Prerequisite: One of PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 305, PSYC 307, PSYC 308, PSYC 358., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PSYC_V 421, Course Title: Environmental Psychology, Course Description: Psychological theory and research on the interaction between organisms and the physical environment; emphasis on applications to the design and management of constructed and natural environments. Strongly recommended: PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 300, PSYC 308, PSYC 309, PSYC 314, PSYC 319. Restricted to students with third-year standing or higher., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PSYC_V 449, Course Title: Honours Seminar and Essay, Course Description: Students carry out a research project and report on its development during seminars. Students also discuss research by Departmental staff, with emphasis on choice of problems, research design and data analysis. Intended for students in their graduating year. Restricted to students in Honours Psychology, in fourth-year standing or higher. Prerequisite: PSYC 349., Credits: 	6

Course ID: PPGA_V 310, Course Title: Designing for Global Community Development, Course Description: Design methodologies for exploring global community development processes relating to achieving the global Sustainable Development Goals. Prerequisite: Second year standing or higher., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PPGA_V 503, Course Title: Measurement and Data Analysis for Policy, Course Description: Fundamental quantitative tools for policy analysis and program evaluation, including measurement, data visualization, and regression analysis. Introduction of skills for the design and implementation of quantitative policy analysis. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PPGA_V 504, Course Title: Policy Analysis and Evaluation, Course Description: Fundamentals of policy analysis and program evaluation for a professional context. Standard tools of policy analysis, risk assessment, and evaluation to design policy interventions and implement monitoring and evaluation systems for effectiveness. Case studies for government, international organizations, and NGOs. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PPGA_V 545, Course Title: Ecology for Policy, Course Description: Ecological systems for diverse policy contexts including: health, agriculture, water, resource management, tourism, spatial planning, and conservation. Innovative progress from policies and policy frameworks that better reflect ecological dynamics, and the design of appropriate policy and governance responses. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PPGA_V 581, Course Title: Behavioural Foundations for Public Policy, Course Description: Basic concepts in social and cognitive psychology, judgment and decision-making and behavioral economics in shaping policy formation and implementation. Application of experimental findings and concepts emanating from behavioral research to the design and implementation of policy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RES_V 504, Course Title: Survey Design in Interdisciplinary Environmental Social Science, Course Description: Survey design focusing on stated and revealed environmental preferences, choices, behaviour and values. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RES_V 505, Course Title: Qualitative Methods in Interdisciplinary Contexts, Course Description: Research design, data quality, analysis, representation, ethics review, structured and unstructured interviews, field observations, survey design. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RES_V 542, Course Title: Integrated Assessment, Course Description: Basic skills for quantitative analysis including probability, validity of quantitative statements and experimental design to test hypothesis validity. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 401, Course Title: Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control, Course Description: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control. Equivalency: PATH 477, Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 410, Course Title: Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions, Course Description: Improving public health by developing the skills to design and deliver pragmatic, effective health behavior change interventions., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 500, Course Title: Analytical Methods in Epidemiological Research, Course Description: Basic epidemiological designs as a framework for commonly used biostatistical techniques such as the Mantel-Haenszel, chi-squared, linear and logistic regression, and survival analysis. Computer packages will be available for computation of assignments. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 567, SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 502, Course Title: Epidemiological Methods 1, Course Description: Sources and uses of epidemiologic data for health services planning and administration including methods of data collection and study design. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 503, Course Title: Epidemiological Methods 2, Course Description: Critical thinking in epidemiology; principles and methods of study design; context for epidemiological investigations of human health. Prerequisite: SPPH 502 and one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 506, Course Title: Quantitative Research Methods, Course Description: Major quantitative research designs, measurement reliability and validity, common data sources used, internal and external validity, research proposals, and peer review. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 506 or SPPH 548. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 510, Course Title: Survey Methods in Health Measurement, Course Description: Concepts and techniques of measurement in epidemiological research. Topics covered include validity, reliability and misclassification, scale design and the construction of questionnaires and indices for both health outcomes and exposures. Prerequisite: One of SPPH 400, SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 512, Course Title: The Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials, Course Description: Ethical considerations, intention-to-treat versus efficacy trials, principles of sampling and exclusion, methods of allocation and techniques of randomization, parallel versus cross over design, monitoring treatment outcomes, adverse effects, stopping rules, analytic techniques and data interpretation, and logistical issues in the management of clinical trials. Prerequisite: One of SPPH 502, SPPH 513. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 513, Course Title: Clinical Epidemiology, Course Description: Principles and methods of epidemiology are applied to clinical problems. Evaluation and design of laboratory and clinical tests and of therapeutic interventions. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 530, Course Title: Epidemiology of Occupational and Environmental Health, Course Description: Design and analysis of etiologic research in occupational health. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 551, Course Title: Pharmacoepidemiology, Course Description: Principles and applications of pharmacoepidemiology. Practical skills in designing, conducting, and appraising studies of medications in large populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 551 or PHAR 561. Prerequisite: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 565, Course Title: Ergonomics, Course Description: Human factors in workplace design, anthropometry, work physiology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 571, Course Title: Public Health, Transportation, and the Built Environment, Course Description: Health issues associated with transportation and the built environment; design of urban form for non-motorized transportation for the improvement of personal and environmental health; factors that impact transportation choices; applying findings from research to specific transportation planning processes and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of PLAN 579 or SPPH 571. Equivalency: PLAN579 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SCIE_V 320, Course Title: Socio-Ecological Systems Research, Course Description: Research design and methods for socio-ecological systems research. Students work directly with faculty mentors to conduct research on contemporary topics such as climate resilience, food security, and environmental sustainability. [1.5-0-1] Prerequisite: Third-year standing and instructor's permission, Credits: 	3

Course ID: SGES_V 501, Course Title: Integration Project, Course Description: Design, analysis, and implementation of technology to create a bench-scale smart grid energy system. Assessment of technology based on sustainability, market, policy and regulatory considerations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: SOWK_V 420, Course Title: Introduction to Social Work Research, Course Description: Theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. Development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 420 or 320. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SOCI_V 217, Course Title: Research Methods, Course Description: Introduction to research designs and methodologies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SOCI_V 380, Course Title: Sociological Methods: Survey Research, Course Description: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 217., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SOIL_V 524, Course Title: Instrumentation for Biometeorology, Course Description: The theory, design and evaluation of instrumentation for biometeorological research. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: STAT_V 300, Course Title: Intermediate Statistics for Applications, Course Description: Further topics in statistical inference, including parametric and non-parametric methods, goodness-of-fit methods, analysis of variance and covariance, regression analysis, categorical data analysis, experimental designs, time series, model fitting, and statistical computing. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: One of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, BUSI 291, COMM 191, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, KIN 206, LFS 252, POLI 380, PSYC 218, PSYC 278. Equivalency: COMM411, Credits: 	3

Course ID: STAT_V 335, Course Title: Statistics in Quality Assurance, Course Description: Philosophy of quality improvement and total quality control. Definitions of quality. Deming's principles, Ishikawa's tools, control charts, acceptance sampling, continuous improvement, quality design. Credit cannot be obtained for both STAT 335 and WOOD 335. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300., Credits: 	3

Course ID: STAT_V 404, Course Title: Design and Analysis of Experiments, Course Description: Theory and application of analysis of variance for standard experimental designs, including blocked, nested, factorial and split plot designs. Fixed and random effects, multiple comparisons, analysis of covariance. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar). [3-0-1] Prerequisite: STAT305, one of MATH 152, MATH 221, or MATH 223. Corequisite: ECON 326 or STAT 306., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LIBE_V 565, Course Title: Special Course in Subject Matter Field, Course Description: Courses in various subject matter fields designed to bring teachers up to date in recent findings in each field. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3-6
Course ID: THTR_V 305, Course Title: Scenery Design I, Course Description: Principles and practice of scenery design for the performing arts., Credits: 	3
Course ID: THTR_V 306, Course Title: Costume Design I, Course Description: Principles and practice of costume design for the performing arts., Credits: 	3
Course ID: THTR_V 307, Course Title: Lighting Design I, Course Description: The optical, distribution, and control systems used in stage lighting design., Credits: 	3
Course ID: THTR_V 308, Course Title: Sound Design, Course Description: Audio design and production., Credits: 	3
Course ID: THTR_V 405, Course Title: Scenery Design II, Course Description: Exploration of complex scenery design and development of design portfolio. Prerequisite: [THTR305], Credits: 	3
Course ID: THTR_V 406, Course Title: Costume Design II, Course Description: Complex problems and selected historical studies in costume design. Prerequisite: THTR 306., Credits: 	3
Course ID: THTR_V 407, Course Title: Lighting Design II, Course Description: Complex design and advanced technologies in stage lighting and scenography. Prerequisite: THTR 307., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THTR_V 505, Course Title: Scenery Design Studio I, Course Description: Scenery design for theatre and other performance forms. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THTR_V 506, Course Title: Costume Design Studio I, Course Description: Costume design for theatre and other performance forms. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THTR_V 507, Course Title: Scenery Design Studio II, Course Description: Complex scenery design for opera, dance, theatre, and other performance forms. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THTR_V 508, Course Title: Costume Design Studio II, Course Description: Complex costume design for opera, dance, theatre, and other performance forms. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THTR_V 551, Course Title: Lighting Design Studio 1, Course Description: Lighting design for theatre and other performance forms. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THFL_V 100, Course Title: The Art of Storytelling for Stage and Screen, Course Description: Fundamental elements of the art of storytelling as approached within each of the core areas taught in the Department of Theatre and Film: Acting/Directing, Design and Production, and Film Production. Restricted to students in one of the following BFA programs: Major in Acting; Major in Film Production; Major in Theatre Design and Production, Credits: 	3

Course ID: THFL_V 304, Course Title: Production Design, Course Description: The tools and processes used by set designers, art directors, and production designers in North America. Prerequisite: One of THTR 205, THTR 305, FIPR 233., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THFL_V 402, Course Title: Professional Portfolio Preparation for Live and Digital Performance, Course Description: Preparation to transition into the theatre and film industry. Portfolio development, visual identity, and skills to support professional performance practices aligned with theatre and film professional associations. Restricted to students in third or fourth-year in one of the following programs: Major in Film Production; Major in Theatre Design and Production. Prerequisite: One of THTR 305, THTR 306, THTR 307, THTR 308, FIPR 333., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THFL_V 599, Course Title: Production, Course Description: Assigned projects in Theatre and Film design and production. Restricted to students in the MFA THTR and MFA FIPR programs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: UFOR_V 100, Course Title: Greening the City, Course Description: Roles played by urban forestry and greenspace systems in a rapidly changing world; topics include urban ecology, urban forest conservation, urban forest management, climate change, society and human well-being, design and planning, urban/rural interface issues, and urban forest policy. [2-0-2], Credits: 	3
Course ID: UFOR_V 110, Course Title: Introduction to Urban Forest Design, Course Description: Basic concepts of landscape design as it relates to urban forestry., Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 330, Course Title: Environmental Justice and Urban Green Equity, Course Description: Theory, concepts and applications of urban green equity and urban environmental justice with particular focus on implications for urban forest policy, planning, management, and design. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Third-year standing., Credits: 	3
Course ID: UFOR_V 415, Course Title: Plant Design, Course Description: An introduction to the design of enhanced environments through the use of plants., Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 420, Course Title: Ecology of Urban Green Infrastructure, Course Description: The nature and dynamics of urban ecosystems with emphasis on urban forests and greenspaces. The role of green infrastructure in urban sustainability with particular focus on the ecological impact of urban forest management, design, and policy decisions. Credit may be granted for only one of UFOR 420 or UFOR 520. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing. Equivalency: UFOR 520, Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 495, Course Title: Biodiversity in Urban Areas, Course Description: Urban centres can be designed and managed to contribute to biodiversity conservation commitments. Topics include designing human-dominated landscapes to promote biodiversity, the tools required, assessing outcomes, and the benefits and negatives of nature in the city. Prerequisite: One of FRST 201, NRES 201, BIOL 230. or permission of the instructor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 520, Course Title: Ecology of Urban Green Infrastructure, Course Description: The nature and dynamics of urban ecosystems with emphasis on urban forests and greenspaces. The role of green infrastructure in urban sustainability with particular focus on the ecological impact of urban forest management, design, and policy decisions. Credit may be granted for only one of UFOR 420 or UFOR 520. [3-0-1] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: URSY_V 530, Course Title: Urban Systems Engineering, Course Description: Technical infrastructure systems that support communities: water; waste and storm water; solid waste; transportation; energy and data. Systems services and demands; technical alternatives; distribution systems; modelling, design, construction, operations and maintenance issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: VANT_V 150, Course Title: Sustainability and Engineering Design, Course Description: Topics in sustainability, including the impact of technology on the environment and society, and fundamentals of engineering design. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [1-0-2; 1-0-2], Credits: 	3

Course ID: VANT_V 151, Course Title: Multi-disciplinary Engineering Design Project, Course Description: Design project that culminates in student-led project fair. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: VANT 150.
