Course ID: AMNE_V 101, Course Title: Greek and Latin Roots of English, Course Description: Greek and Latin roots of English vocabulary and grammar, with an introduction to language history and Greek and Roman culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 101 or AMNE 101., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 151, Course Title: Greek and Roman Mythology, Course Description: Greek and Roman mythology and its interpretation. Emphasis on ancient texts read in English translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 105 or AMNE 151., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 331, Course Title: Jewish Law, Course Description: History, sources, theoretical issues and current state of research about early Jewish legal traditions, focusing on close readings of classic primary texts in English translations. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 335 or AMNE 331., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 383, Course Title: Modern Jewish Ethics in Historical Perspective, Course Description: Readings from key texts in English translation, tracing how Jewish approaches to ethical issues evolved from biblical times to the present. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 313 or AMNE 383., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ASTU_V 310, Course Title: Co-operative Work Placement I, Course Description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Orientation workshops. Final work term report required. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program. Prerequisite: 6 credits first-year English or Arts I; 6 credits of science; 6 credits of literature; satisfaction of Faculty language requirement. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ASIA_V 395, Course Title: Modern Persian Literature, Course Description: Modern Persian literature, including fiction, drama, and/or poetry, of Iran, Afghanistan, and/or Tajikistan dating from the mid-19th to the 21st century (in English translation)., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ASIA_V 412, Course Title: Pre-Modern Chinese Poetry (Pre-Qin to Tang), Course Description: Features and evolution of major pre-Chinese poetry from the 11th century B.C.E. to the 10th century C.E.; analytical reading of signature poems by selected poets in English translation in the pre-modern Chinese poetic tradition during this historical period., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ASIA_V 413, Course Title: Pre-Modern Chinese Poetry (Tang to Qing), Course Description: The features and evolution of pre-Chinese poetry from the 10th century to the 19th century; analytical reading of signature poems by selected poets in English translation in the pre-modern Chinese poetic tradition during this historical period., Credits: 	3

Course ID: CRWR_V 415, Course Title: Workshop in Literary Translation I, Course Description: A workshop class in literary translation. Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing. Prerequisite: Proficiency in a language other than English., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: CRWR_V 515, Course Title: Advanced Workshop in Literary Translation I, Course Description: Prerequisite: Proficiency in a language other than English. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 100, Course Title: Reading and Writing about Language and Literatures, Course Description: A writing-intensive introduction to language and literary studies through the exploration of texts in their critical and theoretical contexts. Fulfills the first-year component of the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement. Open only to students in the Faculty of Arts. Recommended for students intending to become English majors. Essays are required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 120, Course Title: Literature and Criticism, Course Description: Enriched study of selected works of literature from a number of critical perspectives. Open to students with a BC-equivalent mark of A (86%) in English 12 or B+ (80%) in English Literature 12. Essays are required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 121, Course Title: Introduction to Literary Theory, Course Description: Enriched study of various theories of literature. Open to students with a BC-equivalent mark of A (86%) in English 12 or B+ (80%) in English Literature 12. Essays are required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 200, Course Title: Principles of Literary Studies, Course Description: A collaboratively-taught exploration and application of key scholarly, theoretical and critical approaches informing the study of literatures in English. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 210, Course Title: An Introduction to English Honours, Course Description: Comprehensive overview of key periods, genres, and methods in English studies for students entering the English Honours program. Restricted to students in Honours programs., Credits: 	6

Course ID: ENGL_V 224, Course Title: World Literature in English, Course Description: English literature produced outside Britain and North America. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 228, Course Title: Topics in Literary and/or Cultural Studies, Course Description: Current research interests in English studies. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 248, Course Title: Mystery and Detective Fiction, Course Description: Thematic and generic approaches to mystery, crime, and detective writing in English, primarily short-fiction and novels; may also include comics, radio, film, and television. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 300, Course Title: Introduction to Critical Theory, Course Description: Analysis of theoretical methods and critical approaches practiced in the discipline of English studies. Required of all students in the English Honours Literature and Language & Literature programs. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 301, Course Title: Technical Writing, Course Description: Study of the principles of written communication in general business and professional activities, and practice in the preparation of abstracts, proposals, reports, and correspondence. Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 318, Course Title: History of the English Language: Early History, Course Description: Principles of language change and language typology. The development of the English language from its Indo-European origins to the end of the Anglo-Saxon period. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 319, Course Title: History of the English Language: Later History, Course Description: Principles of language change. The development and spread of the English language from the Norman Conquest to the Modern English period. Prerequisite: Knowledge of the International Phonetic Alphabet (via ENGL 318, ENGL 330 or the equivalent). Recommended: ENGL 318., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 321, Course Title: English Grammar and Usage, Course Description: Descriptive approaches to the English language. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 323, Course Title: Varieties of English, Course Description: Study of geographical, social, and/or urban dialects of English. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 326, Course Title: Studies in the English Language, Course Description: Topics in the history or structure of the English language. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 335, Course Title: Digital Humanities, Course Description: Tools, methods, and theories of digital humanities as used in English scholarship. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 342, Course Title: Introduction to Old English, Course Description: Old English vocabulary, grammar, and translation, with readings in poetry and prose. Course ID: ENGL_V 343, Course Title: Anglo-Saxon and Early Medieval Literature, Course Description: Readings in the literature of early medieval (pre-1200) Britain and its neighbours, in modern English translation. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 374, Course Title: Post-colonial Literature, Course Description: World literature in English focusing on decolonization and anti-colonial thought. Consult department website for current year's offerings. Credit will be granted for up to 6 credits of ENGL 374 and/or 478. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 376, Course Title: Special Topics - Place, Power, Poetics and Narrative Discourse, Course Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the program website ( https://english.ubc.ca/courses/ ) for further details., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ENGL_V 489, Course Title: Language Majors Seminar, Course Description: Required of all Language Majors. Course ID: ENGL_V 490, Course Title: Literature Majors Seminar, Course Description: Required of all Literature Majors. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GERN_V 315, Course Title: The Magic of Translation, Course Description: Tools and concepts to create original translations across English and German. Course ID: GMST_V 415, Course Title: German Literary Translation, Course Description: Theory, methodology and practice of translating literary texts between English and German. Course ID: HIST_V 420, Course Title: Topics in Canadian History, Course Description: May include immigration, French-English relations, the growth of the state, health and welfare, or the family., Credits: 	3-6

Equivalency: CONS 340, Credits: 	3

Course ID: NRES_V 341, Course Title: Intermediate Geomatics for Natural Resource Management, Course Description: Applications of remote sensing, image analysis, advanced spatial analysis and geoprocessing for natural resource management. Priority enrolment to students in the Faculty of Forestry. Students may receive credit for only one of NRES 341, NRES 340, CONS 340. Prerequisite: NRES 241. Third-year standing. Equivalency: NRES 340, CONS 340, Credits: 	3

Course ID: NRES_V 441, Course Title: Advanced Geomatics for Natural Resource Management, Course Description: Advanced applications of remote sensing, image analysis, spatial analysis and geoprocessing for natural resource management. Priority enrolment to students in the Faculty of Forestry. Students may receive credit for only one of FRST 443, NRES 443, NRES 441. Prerequisite: One of NRES 340, NRES 341. Fourth-year standing. Equivalency: FRST 443, NRES 443, Credits: 	3

Course ID: CONS_V 412, Course Title: Belowground Ecosystems, Course Description: Current concepts, methods, and applications of belowground ecology with emphasis on biotic interactions in soil; to understand the roles that aboveground and belowground communities play in regulating the structure and function of terrestrial ecosystems and their responses to global change. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Fourth year standing in the Faculty of Forestry or a Bachelor of Science Program awarded by any Faculty. Equivalency: APBI412, Credits: 	3

Course ID: CONS_V 488, Course Title: Contemporary Forestry and Conservation in China (UBC Global Seminar Series), Course Description: This is a one-month UBC Global Seminar program in China allows students to learn forestry and conservation in Asia through lectures and field trips to nature reserves, plantations, wood industry firms and national parks in China. Prerequisite: Third-year standing., Credits: 	6

Course ID: SOCI_V 360, Course Title: Sociology and Natural Resources, Course Description: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102., Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 100, Course Title: Greening the City, Course Description: Roles played by urban forestry and greenspace systems in a rapidly changing world; topics include urban ecology, urban forest conservation, urban forest management, climate change, society and human well-being, design and planning, urban/rural interface issues, and urban forest policy. [2-0-2], Credits: 	3
Course ID: UFOR_V 110, Course Title: Introduction to Urban Forest Design, Course Description: Basic concepts of landscape design as it relates to urban forestry., Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 231, Course Title: Introductory Statistical Methods for Urban Forestry, Course Description: Basic theories and practice of statistical methods in an urban forestry context. Intended only for students in the Bachelor of Urban Forestry program. Students in the Bachelor of Science, Natural Resources should take NRES 231., Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 402, Course Title: Urban Forestry Administration, Policy and Law, Course Description: The administrative, legal, policy, and business environments for urban forestry governance, management, and planning. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: UFOR 300. And third year standing., Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 512, Course Title: Urban Forest Governance, Course Description: Governance theory and ways of applying a governance perspective to strategic decision-making in urban forestry. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: UFOR_V 531, Course Title: Master of Urban Forestry Leadership Capstone Course, Course Description: Application of urban forestry concepts and skills in a project-based learning experience. Prerequisite: FCOR 599. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: WOOD_V 225, Course Title: Communications Strategies, Course Description: Strategies for thinking critically and writing effectively about topics that engage practitioners in Forestry, particularly in Wood Products Processing. Planning, drafting and editing of professional-quality documents for specialists and other stakeholders. Developing oral presentation skills. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of FRST 150, NRES 150, LFS 150, WRDS 150. or ENGL 1st or WRCM 1st. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENGL_V 355, Course Title: Romantic Period Literature, Course Description: British and Global literature, 1780-1830, from the period of the French Revolution to the Reform Act and the Abolition of Slavery in the British Empire. May encompass multiple genres and contexts. Consult department website for current year's offerings. Credit will be granted for up to 6 credits of ENGL 355 and/or 359. For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: FREN_V 101, Course Title: Beginners' French I, Course Description: Basic vocabulary, the rudiments of grammar and familiarization with cultures of the French-speaking world. This course is aligned with level A1 objectives of the CEFR. Credit will be granted for only one of FREN 101 or FREN 103., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 103, Course Title: Intensive Beginners' French, Course Description: Fundamentals of the French language. Recommended for students who are not complete beginners in French. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives. Credit will be granted for FREN 103 or both FREN 101, FREN 102., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 301, Course Title: Intermediate French I, Course Description: Refinement of reading, writing and speaking skills through the study of contemporary literature and other authentic documents of the French-speaking world. This course is aligned with level B1 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended pre-requisites: one of FREN 12, FREN 112, FREN 202, or assignment based on placement test., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 311, Course Title: Introduction to Literature in French, Course Description: Critical reading of foundational literary texts in French from genres of prose fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and theatre. Prerequisite: One of FREN 123, FREN 302., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 321, Course Title: Critical Writing, Course Description: Practical tools for university-level writing in French. Apply stylistic devices and rhetorical structures to form questions and arguments, analyse literary and cultural objects, and produce a variety of essay genres. Prerequisite: One of FREN 123, FREN 302., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 331, Course Title: Arts, Cultures and Society from the Middle Ages to the Revolution, Course Description: Exploration of early French culture and literature from the Middle Ages to the close of the Early Modern period and the French Revolution; the impact of society on the arts and vice versa. Prerequisite: One of FREN 311, FREN 321 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 341, Course Title: Arts, Cultures and Society from Romanticism to the Present Day, Course Description: Exploration of modern and contemporary French culture and literature from the early 19th century to the present day; the impact of society on the arts and vice versa. Prerequisite: One of FREN 311, FREN 321 and one of FREN 224, FREN 401., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 344, Course Title: Techniques of Oral Expression in French I, Course Description: Training in formal oral presentation in French. Emphasis on structured expression and oral delivery. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours Program in French. Prerequisite: One of FREN 215, FREN 225. 68% or better in FREN 215 is recommended., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 346, Course Title: French at Work, Course Description: Communicative French for students preparing for a career in the francophone world. This course is aligned with the B1 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended pre-requisites: one of FREN 123, FREN 302., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 352, Course Title: French Grammar, Course Description: Principles of grammar theory and contextualized French grammatical concepts. Emphasis on terminology and analysis of grammatical issues. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives. Recommended pre-requisite: FREN 401, FREN 402. Prerequisite: One of FREN 123, FREN 302., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 353, Course Title: Advanced French Grammar, Course Description: Advanced grammar theory and critical analysis of difficult French grammatical structures. Emphasis on autonomous examination of complex grammatical issues. Recommended pre-requisite: FREN 401, FREN 402. Prerequisite: One of FREN 223, FREN 352., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 357, Course Title: Translation, Course Description: Principles, practical strategies and methods of translation from French to English and English to French. Overview of the main challenges involved in intercultural communication. Recommended pre-requisite: FREN 353. Prerequisite: One of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 370, Course Title: Introduction to French Linguistics, Course Description: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French linguistics, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced language study in French. Prerequisite: Either (a) FREN 223 or (b) all of FREN 352, FREN 401., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 395, Course Title: Special Topics Abroad, Course Description: Study of Francophone literature, history, culture, or communities in an authentic context. Topics and locations may vary. Consult Department for current offerings. Recommendation: CEFR A2 French proficiency level., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: FREN_V 401, Course Title: Upper-Intermediate French I, Course Description: Communicative proficiency at an autonomous level: vocabulary enrichment, pronunciation practice, grammatical analysis and development of efficient reading and writing techniques. This course is aligned with level B2 objectives of the CEFR. Recommended pre-requisites: one of FREN 123, FREN 302, or French Immersion 12, or assignment based on placement test., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 407, Course Title: Medieval French Literature, Course Description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of French-language literature of the Middle Ages (11th-15th centuries) in their historical context Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 408, Course Title: Renaissance: Studies in 16th-century French Literature, Course Description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of sixteenth-century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 409, Course Title: Ancients and Moderns: Studies in 17th-century French Literature, Course Description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of seventeenth-century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 410, Course Title: Enlightenment and Revolution: Studies in 18th-century French Literature, Course Description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of eighteenth-century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 413, Course Title: Tradition and Modernity: Studies in 19th-century French Literature, Course Description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of nineteenth-century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 415, Course Title: French Digital Culture, Course Description: Contemporary issues and debates on how media and digital technologies have impacted French culture and society. Examines how text, language, and writing are used in digital media. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 416, Course Title: Contemporary French Literature and Culture, Course Description: Aesthetic and ideological trends of twentieth- and twenty-first century French literature in their historical context. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 417, Course Title: Popular Fiction, Course Description: Popular genres in modern French fiction, including science fiction, crime, romance, fantasy and historical fiction. Aesthetic characteristics, historical context and cultural relevance. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 427, Course Title: French Cinema, Course Description: Study of major past and contemporary French film productions. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 431, Course Title: Indigenous Literatures of Francophone Canada, Course Description: Study of the literature and cinema of First Nations, Inuit and M�tis creators working in French and in Francophone spaces in Canada. Recommendation: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 441, Course Title: Francophone Literatures and Cultures of North America, Course Description: Forms of French language cultural expression in North America in their historical context. Discussion of issues around minority linguistic and cultural rights. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 450, Course Title: Old French, Course Description: The phonetics, grammar, and vocabulary of major Old French dialects; corpus of various literary texts. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FREN 311, FREN 321 or (b) all of FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 223, FREN 225, FREN 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 451, Course Title: French Phonetics, Course Description: Theory and practice of the sound system of the French language. Anatomy of speech production, sound discrimination, phonetic description and transcription. Prerequisite: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 455, Course Title: Creative Writing in French, Course Description: Theory, techniques and practice of creative writing in French in a variety of genres. Prerequisite: FREN 321 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 457, Course Title: Advanced Translation, Course Description: Extensive practice in French-English and English-French translation of a wide range of texts and discourses, such as literary, legal, medical, administrative, commercial materials. Analysis of linguistic and cultural problems posed by translation of specialized material. Prerequisite: [FREN357], Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 460, Course Title: History of the French Language, Course Description: Overview of the development of the French language from its Latin roots to its modern forms. Examination of the internal and external factors which brought about changes in its phonology, morphology, syntax and lexis. Prerequisite: FREN 353 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 470, Course Title: Studies in Modern French Linguistics, Course Description: Current topics in French linguistics. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: All of FREN 353, FREN 370. Corequisite: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 472, Course Title: Morphology and Syntax of the French Language, Course Description: Analytical principles pertaining to the study of words and word-stems (morphology), and phrases and sentences (syntax) in written and spoken French. Prerequisite: [FREN353, FREN370] Corequisite: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 474, Course Title: Lexicology and Semantics of the French Language, Course Description: Study of the vocabulary of modern French, focusing on basic principles in lexical semantics, lexicology, phraseology, lexicography, terminology and new technologies, neology. Prerequisite: [FREN353, FREN370] Corequisite: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 476, Course Title: French Language and Societies, Course Description: Study of language in its social context, covering aspects of sociolinguistics within and across the French-speaking communities of the world. Prerequisite: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 477, Course Title: Contemporary Varieties of French, Course Description: Study of the different varieties (or dialects) of contemporary French and issues related to French-speaking communities around the world. Prerequisite: FREN 353 and one of FREN 353, FREN 225., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 480, Course Title: French Theory, Course Description: Core ideas of French theorists. Influence of French theory on the social sciences and humanities, focusing on Marxism, feminism, structuralism, deconstruction, postmodernism and postcolonialism. Prerequisite: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 485, Course Title: Early Encounters: Travel Literature and Colonial Writing in French, Course Description: Narratives of travel and exploration in French before 1800 and their relationship to colonization, knowledge production and representations of the self and others. Prerequisite: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 402, FREN 225., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 495, Course Title: Research Seminar in French Literature and Culture, Course Description: Research on critical topics related to French literature and culture. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: One of FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329 and one of FREN 225, FREN 402., Credits: 	3

Course ID: FREN_V 496, Course Title: Research Seminar in French Language and Linguistics, Course Description: Research on critical topics related to French language and linguistics. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: FREN 353 and FREN 370., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 306, Course Title: History of France, 1461-1715, Course Description: The development of absolute monarchy in France, with emphasis on change and conflict in French society; spiritual and intellectual crisis; the place of France in the emerging European state system; and opposition to the monarchy., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 307, Course Title: French North America to 1803, Course Description: Historical background for understanding the French-speaking peoples of North America: Acadians, Franco-Quebecois, French-Canadians and Cajuns. It also deals extensively with French-Indigenous relations and introduces the student to the historiography of French North America., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 308, Course Title: Quebec from the End of the 18th Century to the Present, Course Description: Relations between the English and the Canadians prior to the Rebellions of 1837-38, the emergence of French Canadian nationalism after 1840, the impact of State formation and industrialization in Quebec, the Quiet Revolution, and the independence movement., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 323, Course Title: Empires, Wars, and Revolutions in Europe and the Americas,1763-1838, Course Description: Political, social, cultural, and intellectual transformations that reshaped the Atlantic world between 1763 and 1838; special attention will be given to the American, French, and Haitian Revolutions, the Latin American Wars of Independence and Canadian rebellions., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 346, Course Title: History of Modern France, Course Description: Political, social, and cultural history of France from the Revolution of 1789 to the present. France's journey toward democracy; particular focus on the changing nature of French culture and society., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 367, Course Title: Europe in the Age of the Enlightenment, Course Description: Europe during the age of the Enlightenment, from the end of the religious wars to the French Revolution, with emphasis on political, social, cultural, and intellectual changes in their global context., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 368, Course Title: Europe in the 19th Century, Course Description: An investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the 20th century. Topics of particular importance are: domestic politics; the interaction of states; the formation of new states; social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization; major cultural expressions of the century., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 413, Course Title: Imagining the Nation: 19th- and 20th-Century Canada, Course Description: The political and intellectual history of the concept of the nation in French and English Canada, and the different forms of nationalism it inspired from the middle of the nineteenth century to the 1995 Quebec Referendum., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 420, Course Title: Topics in Canadian History, Course Description: May include immigration, French-English relations, the growth of the state, health and welfare, or the family., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: LLED_V 323, Course Title: Teaching and Learning Modern Languages: Elementary and Middle Years, Course Description: Curriculum and methods of teaching in modern languages (including Chinese, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Punjabi, Russian, and Spanish). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LLED_V 324, Course Title: Teaching and Learning French: Elementary and Middle Years, Course Description: An introduction to communicative core French teaching and learning for generalists. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LLED_V 372, Course Title: Teaching French Language and Literacy: Secondary, Course Description: Language of instruction is French. Pass/Fail for B.Ed. students. Non-B.Ed. students are eligible for percentage grading or Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3
Course ID: LLED_V 421, Course Title: Gramligne: Learning and Teaching Grammar in Text for the Second Language Classroom, Course Description: Taught in French., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LLED_V 426, Course Title: Principles and Practice of French Program Development, Course Description: Taught in French. The development and implementation of French Immersion, Program Cadre, and French as a Second language Programs for preschool, elementary, secondary, or adult., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LLED_V 523, Course Title: Teacher Action Research in Language and Literacy Education, Course Description: Taught in French. Understanding of the literature and methods associated with teacher (action) research in language and literacy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RMST_V 300, Course Title: History of the Romance Languages, Course Description: Development of the Romance language family from its origins in Latin to contemporary varieties. Emphasis on French, Italian, Portuguese and Spanish. Prerequisite: A beginners' knowledge (A1) in at least of one of the Romance languages is highly recommended., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RMST_V 305, Course Title: Introduction to Romance Language Cinema, Course Description: Overview of the history, aesthetics and characteristics of films in French, Italian, Spanish, and/or Portuguese. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 234 or RMST 305., Credits: 	3
Course ID: RMST_V 321, Course Title: French Literature from the Middle Ages to the Revolution, Course Description: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works., Credits: 	3
Course ID: RMST_V 322, Course Title: French Literature since the Revolution, Course Description: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RMST_V 325, Course Title: French Cultural Identities, Course Description: Aspects of French culture through a set of key concepts that weave across French history, politics, and social structures. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 325 or FREN 380., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RMST_V 375, Course Title: The Caribbean: Frontiers of the Romance World, Course Description: Literature and culture from the island of Hispaniola (Haiti, Dominican Republic) and the French Caribbean from a comparative perspective., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Genome Science and Technology courses.
completion: Course ID: GSAT_V 503, Course Title: Directed Studies in Genome Science and Technology, Course Description: Advanced study under the direction of a faculty member composed of laboratory sessions and/or directed readings related to selected areas of genome science and technology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Geographical Sciences courses.
completion: Course ID: GEOS_V 409, Course Title: Advanced Field Studies in Geographical Sciences, Course Description: Advanced research design, field sampling methods, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, data analysis and management; self-directed field-based research. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of GEOB 309, GEOS 309. Third-year standing in Geographical Sciences, Environmental Sciences or Major in Geography (Environmental and Sustainability)., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Geographical Sciences courses.
completion: Course ID: GEOS_V 449, Course Title: Undergraduate Thesis, Course Description: Original research on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a faculty member. Open to 4th year students in Geographical Sciences with appropriate background courses related to the research topic, and permission of the directing faculty member. The 3-credit option is only available to students who complete GEOS 449 in tandem with GEOS 409., Credits: 	3-6

prompt: Tell me about Geographical Sciences courses.
completion: Course ID: GEOS_V 490, Course Title: Student Directed Seminar in Geographical Sciences, Course Description: Self-directed, collaborative studies in physical geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. This course carries science credit. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOB 490, GEOS 490 and GEOG 442. Prerequisite: Third-year standing in Geographical Sciences., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AFST_V 256, Course Title: History of Africa, Course Description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 256 or HIST 256. Equivalency: HIST 256, Credits: 	3

Course ID: ANTH_V 341, Course Title: Museums, Heritage and Memory, Course Description: Museums, galleries, monuments, and other cultural institutions' relations to our perception of history and geography., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: ANTH_V 422, Course Title: Modes of Subsistence, Course Description: The nature of subsistence systems antedating or alternative to modern commercial systems. Introductory survey with basic readings; focus on problems such as the development of complex cultures without agriculture, the ambiguity of hunting and gathering, agricultural and other intensification, orchestration of the use of adjacent microenvironments. Of interest to students of archaeology, anthropology and cultural geography., Credits: 	3

Course ID: CSIS_V 200, Course Title: Critical Engagements in Sexuality Studies, Course Description: Introductory survey to sexuality studies that emphasizes how sexuality intersects with race, gender, class, ability, and geography. Recommended pre-requisite: GRSJ 101., Credits: 	3

Course ID: EOSC_V 425, Course Title: Paleontology, Course Description: Paleobiogeography in the context of plate tectonics. Mass extinction events. Fossilization and biases in the fossil record. Species concepts in paleontology. Biostratigraphy. Paleontological evidence for early life; the colonization of oceanic and terrestrial environments and; the evolution of the primates. [2-3-0] Prerequisite: EOSC 222., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ECON_V 333, Course Title: Economic History of Europe from the Paleolithic to the Industrial Revolution, Course Description: The conditions and causes of long run growth from nomadism to agriculture to industrialized states, including institutions, geography, culture, colonialism, and slave trades. Determinants of the Neolithic, consumer and industrial revolutions, demographic transition and first era of globalization. Prerequisite: One of ECON 101, ECON 310 and one of ECON 102, ECON 311., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENST_V 310, Course Title: Environment and Sustainability, Course Description: Concepts of environment, resources and sustainability; the roles of physical and human geography in understanding the interaction of humans and the environment; introduction to management of environment-resource systems. Credit will be granted for only one of ENST 310 or GEOG 310. Equivalency: GEOG310, Credits: 	3

Course ID: ENST_V 419, Course Title: Research in Environmental Geography, Course Description: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 419 or ENST 419. Equivalency: GEOG 419, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOS_V 303, Course Title: Tropical Ecosystems in a Changing World, Course Description: Biogeography and ecology of tropical systems, including patterns of species diversity, forest dynamics, plant-animal interactions, carbon and nutrient cycling. Impacts of global environmental change and conservation strategies for tropical ecosystems. Recommended pre-requisites: one of GEOB 207, GEOS 207, BIOL 230, FRST 201. [3-0-0], Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOS_V 409, Course Title: Advanced Field Studies in Geographical Sciences, Course Description: Advanced research design, field sampling methods, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, data analysis and management; self-directed field-based research. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of GEOB 309, GEOS 309. Third-year standing in Geographical Sciences, Environmental Sciences or Major in Geography (Environmental and Sustainability)., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOS_V 479, Course Title: Research in Geographic Information Science, Course Description: Students use GIS in primary research applications in conservation biology, crime analysis, and health geography; theoretical and practical aspects considered in a hands-on environment. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: One of GEOB 370, GEOS 370., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOS_V 490, Course Title: Student Directed Seminar in Geographical Sciences, Course Description: Self-directed, collaborative studies in physical geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. This course carries science credit. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOB 490, GEOS 490 and GEOG 442. Prerequisite: Third-year standing in Geographical Sciences., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 121, Course Title: Geography, Environment and Globalization, Course Description: Human geography of the modern world with particular attention to human-environment relationships, urbanization, and regional growth; trade and communications; environment and war; environmental governance and sustainability., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 122, Course Title: Geography, Modernity and Globalization, Course Description: The human geography of the modern world since 1945: global interdependence in economic geography, geopolitics, and cultural geography; consequences of modernization, including demography, urbanization and environmental effects; regional case studies; reactions to modernization., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 210, Course Title: Vancouver and Its Region, Course Description: An integrated approach to the physical and human geography of the Lower Mainland of British Columbia. Field trips., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 290, Course Title: Introduction to the Geography of Canada, Course Description: Selected topics in human geography focusing on the regional distribution of natural resources, population, urban systems, and economic activities., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 310, Course Title: Environment and Sustainability, Course Description: Concepts of environment, resources and sustainability; the roles of physical and human geography in understanding the interaction of humans and the environment; introduction to management of environment-resource systems. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 310 or ENST 310. Equivalency: ENST310, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 329, Course Title: Political Geography, Course Description: Review of political geography and geopolitics; relations among space, power and politics; cases from current global affairs., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 345, Course Title: Theory and Practice in Human Geography, Course Description: A consideration of major intellectual issues and debates in the development of contemporary human geography, in relation to developments in other fields and changes in politics, culture and society., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 346, Course Title: Topics in Geography, Course Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website or contact the Geography undergraduate advisor for details., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: GEOG_V 357, Course Title: Society, Culture & Space, Course Description: The development of social and behavioural geography, focusing on how places, landscapes, and environments both reflect and shape social life. Third year standing is recommended., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 361, Course Title: Critical Geographies of the Economy, Course Description: History and methods of economic geography. Location of resource industries, manufacturing, and service activities with emphasis on British Columbia in its North American and world setting. Recommended for students with no previous exposure to geographies of the economy, before taking other courses in the 36x and 46x series. Recommended pre-requisite: GEOG 122., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 371, Course Title: Research Strategies in Geography, Course Description: Formulating a research problem and selecting an appropriate research strategy. Research strategies range from social scientific survey methods to ethnography. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 374, Course Title: Statistics in Geography, Course Description: Introduction to statistical techniques and their application to geographical problems. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… ., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 390, Course Title: Geography of Selected Regions, Course Description: A geographical analysis of selected regions not regularly included in the Department's offerings in regional geography (e.g., tropical Africa, Oceania). Students should consult the Department regarding regions to be covered., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: GEOG_V 391, Course Title: Modern Europe: Places and Borders, Course Description: An introduction to the present-day human geography of the regions and places between the Atlantic and the Ural Mountains. Restricted to students with at least second-year standing., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 410, Course Title: Environment and Society, Course Description: Geographical analysis of society-environment relations. Relates resource management to environmental politics, political economy, and sustainable development. Perspectives drawn from political ecology and political economy, environmental history and environmental philosophy. Registration is restricted to Geography Majors and Minors or permission of instructor. Recommended: GEOG 310. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 410 or ENST 410. Equivalency: ENST 410 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 419, Course Title: Research in Environmental Geography, Course Description: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year. Registration is restricted to Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of instructor. Recommended: GEOG 313 and 314. Credit will only be granted for one of GEOG 419 or ENST 419. Equivalency: ENST 419, Credits: 	3
Course ID: GEOG_V 424, Course Title: Feminist Geographies, Course Description: An introductory survey of contemporary feminist approaches to human geography., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 429, Course Title: Research in Historical Geography, Course Description: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year. Recommended: Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 442, Course Title: Student Directed Seminar in Human Geography, Course Description: Self-directed, collaborative studies in human geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 442 or GEOG 443. Prerequisite: Third-year standing in human geography., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 447, Course Title: Directed Studies: Off Campus Research, Course Description: Based on project work outside the university, on a topic to be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member and the student. Prerequisite: Open to upper-level students enrolled in the Geography Majors or Honours programs. Permission of the Undergraduate Advisor and supervising faculty member is required., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 448, Course Title: Directed Studies in Geography, Course Description: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member and the student. Prerequisite: Open to upper-level students enrolled in the Geography Majors or Honours programs. Permission of the Undergraduate Advisor and supervising faculty member is required., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 461, Course Title: Urban Political-Economic Geographies, Course Description: Principal theories and debates in urban political economy and political-economic geography, with particular emphasis on global transformations., Credits: 	3
Course ID: GEOG_V 485, Course Title: Geography of China, Course Description: An introduction to the changing cultural, social and economic geography of China., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 497, Course Title: The Arctic, Course Description: Physical and biological characteristics of the circumpolar Arctic, emphasizing terrestrial environments and the impacts on and by humans, including: glacial history; climatology; biogeography/ecology of arctic tundra; human-environment interactions, settlement and exploration; and current environmental, social and economic problems. Prerequisite: At least third-year standing., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 520, Course Title: Themes and Interpretive Issues in Modern Human Geography, Course Description: Themes and interpretive issues in modern human geography. Students from outside Geography require the permission of the Head of the department. Restricted to M.A. GEOG, M.Sc. GEOG, or PhD GEOG. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GEOG_V 571, Course Title: Research Methods in Human Geography, Course Description: Pass/Fail. Restricted to Human Geography graduate students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 256, Course Title: History of Africa, Course Description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 256 or HIST 256. Equivalency: AFST256, Credits: 	3

Course ID: MRNE_V 412, Course Title: Biology of Fishes, Course Description: Classification, physiology, ecology, behaviour and zoogeography of fishes with particular emphasis on those in the marine environment of the British Columbia coast. Prerequisite: A course in comparative vertebrate anatomy., Credits: 	6

Course ID: PHIL_V 461, Course Title: Philosophy of Social Science, Course Description: Topics in the philosophy of science of special concern to the social sciences: the problem of objectivity, the use of models and evidence, causation and causal reasoning, formal methods, the status of social kinds and norms, scientific explanation, laws. Prerequisite: 9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PPGA_V 583, Course Title: Food Security, Course Description: Global food security challenges including: biophysical, economic, nutritional, socio-political, and institutional aspects. Geography of agricultural production, role of price and supply shocks, causes of malnutrition, and environmental impacts. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GERN_V 304, Course Title: German for Reading Knowledge I, Course Description: Reading skills in German leading to a second year reading knowledge in just one term. Students are expected to work largely independently. Course meant for students with no or very little German (i.e. no more than GERN 101). Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 433 or GERN 304. Equivalency: GERM433, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GERN_V 309, Course Title: German in the Workplace, Course Description: Grammatical patterns in application to workplace conditions and requirements with Germanophone business. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 314 or GERN 309. Prerequisite: One of GERM 210, GERN 202. or equivalent. Equivalency: GERM314, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GERN_V 315, Course Title: The Magic of Translation, Course Description: Tools and concepts to create original translations across English and German. Includes theory, methodology, and practice. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 325 or GERN 315. Prerequisite: One of GERM 210, GERN 202. or equivalent. Equivalency: GERM325, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GERN_V 344, Course Title: Discipline and Liberation: Studies in the 19th Century, Course Description: Nineteenth-century Germanophone literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 380 or GERN 344. Equivalency: GERM380, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GERN_V 347, Course Title: Progress and Disaster: Studies in the 20th and 21st Centuries, Course Description: Selected literary works from German-speaking societies against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 390 or GERN 347. Equivalency: GERM390, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GERN_V 401, Course Title: German through Critical Contemporary Topics, Course Description: Discussion and analysis of current issues in a German-speaking seminar format. Spoken and written German communication about critical, societal topics fostering advanced competence. Continuation of GERN 302. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 400 or GERN 401. Equivalency: GERM400, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GERN_V 404, Course Title: German for Reading Knowledge II (Languages for special purposes), Course Description: Multimedia teaching of reading skills in German for special purposes. Students are expected to work largely independently. Focuses on specific topics of the student's choice in the humanities, the natural sciences, economics/business and music and enhances skills in technical reading. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 434 or GERN 404. Prerequisite: One of GERM 433, GERN 304. or equivalent. Course ID: GMST_V 121, Course Title: Fairy Tales and Popular Culture, Course Description: Explore folk and fairy tales from the German-speaking tradition and their adaptations. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 121 or GMST 121. Equivalency: GERM121, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 229, Course Title: Exile, Flight and Migration, Course Description: Transnational narratives about exile, migration and integration in the German-speaking countries. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 206 or GMST 229. Equivalency: GERM206, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 311, Course Title: German Linguistics, Course Description: Basic theories and methodologies of modern German linguistics. Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 318 or GMST 311. Equivalency: GERM318, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 335, Course Title: German Cinema, Course Description: Screening, discussion, and critical analysis of influential cinema from German-speaking societies from the silent era to the 21st century. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 304 or GMST 335. Equivalency: GERM304, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 341, Course Title: Germanophone Literature before 1900, Course Description: Reading and discussion of selected works from German-speaking societies from the Middle Ages to 1900. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 303 or GMST 341. Equivalency: GERM303, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 342, Course Title: Heaven and Earth: Germanophone Culture and Literature before 1700, Course Description: Germanophone literature of the Middle Ages, Renaissance, and Baroque against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 360 or GMST 342. Equivalency: GERM360, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 343, Course Title: Reason and Revolution: Studies in the 18th Century, Course Description: Eighteenth-century Germanophone literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 370 or GMST 343. Equivalency: GERM370, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 346, Course Title: Germanophone Literature 1900-1945, Course Description: Reading and discussion of selected works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in twentieth-century German-speaking societies. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 301 or GMST 346. Equivalency: GERM301, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 347, Course Title: Germanophone Literature after 1945, Course Description: Reading and discussion of selected literary works from German-speaking societies. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 302 or GMST 347. Equivalency: GERM302, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 371, Course Title: Marx, Nietzsche and Freud in Cultural Context, Course Description: Explore the impact of the writings of Karl Marx, Friedrich Nietzsche and Sigmund Freud on the cultures of the Germanspeaking world and draw connections to contemporary debates about identity, family, gender, class, social justice and the philosophy of history., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 415, Course Title: German Literary Translation, Course Description: Theory, methodology and practice of translating literary texts between English and German. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 425 or GMST 415. Prerequisite: One of GERM 325, GERN 315. Equivalency: GERM425, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 424, Course Title: Selected Issues in German-speaking Culture, Course Description: In depth study of one topic from German-speaking cultural history, varying from year to year. Find out which topic/s will be explored in the current or coming year at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 408 or GMST 424. Equivalency: GERM408, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 427, Course Title: Major Controversies in German-speaking Culture, Course Description: Selected debates and controversies in the German-speaking societies. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 411 or GMST 427. Equivalency: GERM411, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 433, Course Title: Germanophone Representations of the Holocaust, Course Description: The Holocaust in German literature and film. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 426 or GMST 433. Prerequisite: Restricted to students with Second Year Standing or above. Equivalency: GERM426, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 436, Course Title: Special Topics in Germanophone Cinema, Course Description: Themes, traditions, and techniques specific to cinema from German-speaking societies. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 409 or GMST 436. Equivalency: GERM409, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 448, Course Title: Religion and Germanophone Literature, Course Description: Religion and literature in German-speaking cultural history. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 404 or GMST 448. Equivalency: GERM404, Credits: 	3

Course ID: GMST_V 475, Course Title: German Media Studies, Course Description: Major themes and methods in German media studies. Find out which themes will be explored in the current or coming year at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of GERM 412 or GMST 475. Equivalency: GERM412, Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 351, Course Title: East Central Europe in the 19th and 20th Centuries, Course Description: Covers the region between Germany and Russia as well as Southeast Europe. Emphasis on comparisons with Western Europe and features that make the area significant to Europe as a whole., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 355, Course Title: Nineteenth Century Germany, Course Description: The political, social, and cultural history of modern Germany during the long nineteenth century (1780s to the early twentieth century)., Credits: 	3
Course ID: HIST_V 356, Course Title: Twentieth-Century Germany, Course Description: The political, social, and cultural history of Germany in the twentieth century., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LLED_V 323, Course Title: Teaching and Learning Modern Languages: Elementary and Middle Years, Course Description: Curriculum and methods of teaching in modern languages (including Chinese, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Punjabi, Russian, and Spanish). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MUSC_V 450, Course Title: Selected Topics in Vocal or Instrumental Genres, Course Description: Intensive study of one genre of music (e.g., orchestral music 17601849; the Lied in Austria and Germany) through analysis and the consideration of cultural milieu and historical development. Specific topics will be announced. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 credits., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: CONS_V 370, Course Title: Indigenous Forestry, Course Description: Principles, issues and ethics germane to working with or for Indigenous Nations or communities, including Indigenous rights and title, relational values and natural resources governance. [3-0-0], Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHIL_V 416, Course Title: Topics in 19th-Century Philosophy, Course Description: Study of a major 19th-century philosopher such as Hegel, Mill or Nietzsche, or school, such as German Idealism. Recommended pre-requisites: one of PHIL 314, PHIL 315, PHIL 316, PHIL 340., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: POLS_V 426, Course Title: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film (in English), Course Description: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and film. Course ID: RELG_V 211, Course Title: History of Christianity II (15th C. C.E. - present), Course Description: The history of Christianity from the Reformation to the present day. Provides an historical overview of Christian thought and its institutions and significant people during the rise of the Reformation in various locales of Europe and beyond (Germany, France, Great Britain, Switzerland, and Scandinavia)., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Global Resource Systems courses.
completion: Course ID: GRS_V 300, Course Title: Global Water and Energy Nexus, Course Description: Energy water nexus for sustaining ecological goods and services, and food security; significance in global resource systems. Prerequisite: One of CHEM 111, CHEM 121 and one of BIOL 112, BIOL 121, BIOL 140., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 101, Course Title: Greek and Latin Roots of English, Course Description: Greek and Latin roots of English vocabulary and grammar, with an introduction to language history and Greek and Roman culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 101 or AMNE 101., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 151, Course Title: Greek and Roman Mythology, Course Description: Greek and Roman mythology and its interpretation. Emphasis on ancient texts read in English translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 105 or AMNE 151., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 215, Course Title: Ancient Greece, Course Description: A survey of the ancient Greek world from the Minoan and Mycenaean (about 2000-1000 BCE) to the Hellenistic Period (323-30 BCE). Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 231 or AMNE 215., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 301, Course Title: The Technical Terms of Medicine and Biological Science, Course Description: Acquaints the student with the Greek and Latin elements from which most specialized terms of modern medicine are constructed. Intended primarily for students planning to enter the medical, pharmaceutical, or biological sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 301 or AMNE 301., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 306, Course Title: Ancient Technology: Greece and Rome, Course Description: The origins, achievements, and social impacts of applied technology in the Greek and Roman world from the Bronze Age to Late Antiquity (c. 1500 BCE - 400 CE), with special attention to archaeological evidence. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 306 or AMNE 306., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 317, Course Title: Alexander the Great and his Empire, Course Description: The rise of Macedon under Philip II leading to its domination of Greece and the overthrow of the Persian Empire by his son, Alexander; the subsequent spread of Greek civilization in the East. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 356 or AMNE 317. Prerequisite: One of CLST 231, AMNE 215., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 323, Course Title: Slavery in the Ancient Greek and Roman World, Course Description: The study and history of slavery in the Greek and Roman worlds as a political, legal, economic, social, and cultural phenomenon. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 320 or AMNE 323., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 326, Course Title: Ancient Greek Warfare, Course Description: Ancient Greek methods and tactics of war plus underlying social, religious and philosophical concepts relating to warfare, through sources in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 329 or AMNE 326., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 332, Course Title: Greek Law, Course Description: The study of Greek legal theory, practice, and institutions from their origin in self-help, through the early lawgivers and their codes, to the developed system of Athens in the fifth and fourth centuries. A variety of test cases from the works of the Greek orators will be explored. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 307 or AMNE 332., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 347, Course Title: Classical Comedy, Course Description: The plays of the Greek and Roman comic dramatists: Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus and Terence, in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 318 or AMNE 347. Prerequisite: Second-year standing and above., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 348, Course Title: Classical Tragedy, Course Description: The plays of the Greek and Roman tragic dramatists, in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 317 or AMNE 348. Recommended pre-requisite: One of CLST 105, AMNE 151. Restricted to students with second year standing or higher., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 376, Course Title: Greek Art and Architecture, Course Description: The visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 331, AMNE 376 or ARTH 331. Equivalency: ARTH 331, Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 395, Course Title: Practicum in Ancient Mediterranean or Near Eastern Archaeology, Course Description: Training in excavation techniques and interpretation through participation in the excavation of a Greek, Roman, or Near Eastern site in Europe or the Middle East. The minimum length of the course is three weeks; it may be repeated once. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 395 and CNRS 335. Students should consult the AMNE Undergraduate Advisor before registering., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: AMNE_V 595, Course Title: Practicum in Ancient Mediterranean or Near Eastern Archaeology, Course Description: Training in excavation techniques and interpretation through participation in the excavation of a Greek, Roman, or Near Eastern site in Europe or the Middle East. The minimum length of the course is three weeks. Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 535 or AMNE 595. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: ARTH_V 331, Course Title: Greek Art and Architecture, Course Description: Visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE. Credit will only be granted for one of ARTH 331, CLST 331, or AMNE 376. Equivalency: AMNE 376, Credits: 	3

Course ID: CLST_V 513, Course Title: The Archaeology of Greek and Roman Technology, Course Description: Material evidence for the technological achievements of the Greek and Roman world. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3-6
Course ID: GREK_V 101, Course Title: Beginning Ancient Greek I, Course Description: Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part I., Credits: 	3
Course ID: GREK_V 102, Course Title: Beginning Ancient Greek II, Course Description: Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part II. Prerequisite: GREK 101., Credits: 	3
Course ID: GREK_V 201, Course Title: Intermediate Ancient Greek I, Course Description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part I. Prerequisite: GREK 102., Credits: 	3

Course ID: GREK_V 202, Course Title: Intermediate Ancient Greek II, Course Description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part II; introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Greek literature. Prerequisite: GREK 201., Credits: 	3
Course ID: GREK_V 351, Course Title: Reading Ancient Greek: Prose, Course Description: Readings in the major authors in Greek prose. Prerequisite: GREK 202., Credits: 	3
Course ID: GREK_V 352, Course Title: Reading Ancient Greek: Verse, Course Description: Readings in the major authors in Greek verse. Prerequisite: GREK 202., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHYS_V 340, Course Title: Revolutions in Understanding the Universe, Course Description: Ancient Greek ideas of substance and forms and modern concepts of forces and fields. The twentieth-century quantum revolution. The modern universe, from quarks and atoms to the big bang. Quantum paradoxes. Not for credit in the faculties of Science and Applied Science. No mathematics beyond Grade 10 required. [3-0-0], Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 261, Course Title: Eden to Exile: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible, Course Description: An overview of the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament), with emphasis on its ancient Near Eastern context; its competing religious perspectives; and its limits as a historical source. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 209 or AMNE 261., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 262, Course Title: Introduction to Judaism and its Texts, Course Description: What is Judaism? An overview of the key texts that have defined the Jewish religion, from the Hebrew Bible through works of contemporary thinkers. Recommended as a basis for upper-level courses in religious studies. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 206 or AMNE 262., Credits: 	3

Course ID: AMNE_V 364, Course Title: Magic, Prophecy, and Divination in the Biblical World, Course Description: Textual, contextual, and comparative exploration of the reciprocal relations between gods and people in the Hebrew Bible, Near Eastern ritual texts, and ancient experience., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HEBR_V 101, Course Title: Beginning Biblical Hebrew I, Course Description: Biblical Hebrew, with an introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of simple biblical texts in the original., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HEBR_V 102, Course Title: Beginning Biblical Hebrew II, Course Description: Biblical Hebrew, with further introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of biblical texts in the original. Prerequisite: HEBR 101., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HEBR_V 201, Course Title: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew I, Course Description: Biblical Hebrew. Devised to enrich vocabulary and grammar and enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of biblical texts. Prerequisite: HEBR 102., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HEBR_V 202, Course Title: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew II, Course Description: Biblical Hebrew. Devised to further enrich vocabulary and grammar and to enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of biblical texts. Prerequisite: HEBR 201., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HEBR_V 205, Course Title: Beginning Biblical Hebrew II, Course Description: Biblical Hebrew, with further introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of biblical texts in the original. Credit will be granted for only one of HEBR 102 or HEBR 205. Prerequisite: HEBR 101., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HEBR_V 301, Course Title: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew I, Course Description: Biblical Hebrew. Devised to enrich vocabulary and grammar and enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of biblical texts. Credit will be granted for only one of HEBR 201 or HEBR 301. Prerequisite: One of HEBR 102, HEBR 205., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HEBR_V 302, Course Title: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew II, Course Description: Biblical Hebrew. Devised to further enrich vocabulary and grammar and to enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of biblical texts. Credit will be granted for only one of HEBR 202 or HEBR 302. Prerequisite: One of HEBR 201, HEBR 301., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HINU_V 400, Course Title: Introduction to Hindi and Urdu Literature, Course Description: Readings of various literary genres in Hindi, Urdu and their medieval equivalents. Modern fiction from India and Pakistan; the Urdu ghazal; medieval Hindi bhakti poetry; readings from the Adi Granth of the Sikhs Hindi film. Discussion in Hindi-Urdu of all materials. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 300., Credits: 	6

Course ID: ADHE_V 328, Course Title: Institutions of Adult Education, Course Description: The history, roles, and activities of institutions in the field of adult education. Institutions in Canada, Great Britain, and the United States are emphasized, and some experiences in other countries are examined. [3-0-0], Credits: 	3

Course ID: ADHE_V 412, Course Title: An Overview of Adult Education, Course Description: Survey of adult education theory and practice in Canada and the world. The focus is on the purpose and participation in, adult education, characteristics of learners, and the training of adult educators. Course ID: AFST_V 256, Course Title: History of Africa, Course Description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 256 or HIST 256. Equivalency: HIST 256, Credits: 	3

Course ID: AFST_V 313, Course Title: Africa from Imperialism to Independence, Course Description: The history of Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: the growth of Islam and Christianity, the impact of European colonialism, the development of nationalism, and the variety of different political and social outcomes after independence. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 313 or HIST 313. Equivalency: HIST 313, Credits: 	3

Course ID: AFST_V 450, Course Title: African Diasporic Culture in African Canadian Communities, Course Description: African diasporic culture in Canadian society, fostering dialogue with members of African Canadian communities on cultural values, traditions, memory, adaptation and change. Course ID: ASL_V 101, Course Title: American Sign Language and Deaf Culture II, Course Description: Skills in using ASL in a range of social contexts. Training in grammar and vocabulary that builds fluency, and in using the language appropriately for meaningful interactions with members of the Deaf community. For students with basic ASL conversational ability. Prerequisite: ASL 100. or by placement.
