Course ID: HIST_V 100, Course Title: What is History?, Course Description: The discipline of history through the study of questions, sources, methods, and controversies. Includes case studies of key turning points in world history to examine what historians do and why it matters., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 101, Course Title: Global History to 1500 CE, Course Description: Introduction to premodern human societies of Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Americas and cultural, political, social, economic, and religious exchanges from a global history perspective and introduction to historical practices., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 106, Course Title: Global Environmental History, Course Description: The impact humans have had on the environment, and the ways in which the physical environment has shaped human history: climate, agriculture, energy use, and urbanization., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 108, Course Title: Global History of Capitalism, Course Description: The history of capitalism in its global dimension from the beginnings to the age of industrialization. An investigation of economies - in both their practices and cultures - around the world and across the ages from ancient times to the modern era., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 109, Course Title: Cultural Histories of Media: From Writing to Tweeting, Course Description: The history of different forms of media in global perspective, with particular attention to audiovisual electronic media., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 201, Course Title: History Through Photographs, Course Description: The discipline of history through the study of photographs. Explores themes such as colonialism, orientalism, the mass media, representations of gender and sexuality, and protest through photographic evidence., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 202, Course Title: Gateway to the Middle Ages, Course Description: Problems and themes of medieval European History through the close study of the people and cultures that produced them., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 220, Course Title: History of Europe, Course Description: Selected themes and historical approaches in European history; may include Europe's history of religious conflict, state formation, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, revolution, total war, globalization, genocide, or environmental change., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 235, Course Title: History of Canada: Moments that Matter, Course Description: An introduction to major turning points in Canadian history. Exploration of the social, political, cultural, and environmental transformations/revolutions that have shaped Canada from early European colonialism to the twenty-first century., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 236, Course Title: Introduction to Public History in Canada: Confronting the Canadian Past, Course Description: An introduction to public history in Canada that explores the politics and practice of representing the past in a variety of sites, such as museums, monuments, and films, and examines questions of historical interpretation, memory, and audience., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 240, Course Title: Health, Illness and Medicine I: From the Ancient World to the Early Modern Period, Course Description: History of western medicine, from the Ancient World to the Enlightenment, with a focus on social and cultural ideas surrounding the body, health, and disease, and the development of medical institutions., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 250, Course Title: Latin American History, Course Description: Exploring themes of colonialism, indigenous life, national imaginaries, dictatorships and transitions to democracy through different forms of telling Latin American history. Includes epistolary writing, maps, eyewitness accounts, chronicles, actions, novels, films, built environment and city plans, testimonios, and plays., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 252, Course Title: Modern Caribbean History, Course Description: A survey of social, cultural and political history of Anglophone, Francophone and Spanish Caribbean from the Haitian Revolution to the present., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 256, Course Title: History of Africa, Course Description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 256 or HIST 256. Equivalency: AFST256, Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 259, Course Title: Science, Medicine, and Technology in the Ancient and Medieval Worlds, Course Description: The history of science, medicine, and technology, emphasizing networks, exchanges, and encounters in a global context., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 270, Course Title: China in World History, Course Description: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China. Equivalency: ASIA270, Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 280, Course Title: Islamic World History, Course Description: The history of the Islamic world in its global dimensions from its origins to the present day through the themes of religion, law, politics, culture, and modernity., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 303, Course Title: History of the Canadian West, Course Description: Selected topics in the history of the Canadian West with an emphasis on the prairie west: the Indian and the fur trade, Louis Riel, prairie settlement, and western social and political protest., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 304, Course Title: Researching Local History from the Ground Up, Course Description: Sources and methods for reconstructing local history that can be used by Social Studies teachers in B.C. The aim is to develop an appreciation of the formative processes and past experiences that created one's familiar community., Credits: 	3
Course ID: HIST_V 309, Course Title: Topics in Sub-Saharan African History, Course Description: Examination of a major theme in the history of Sub-Saharan Africa., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 313, Course Title: Africa from Imperialism to Independence, Course Description: The history of Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: the growth of Islam and Christianity, the impact of European colonialism, the development of nationalism, and the variety of different political and social outcomes after independence. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 313 or HIST 313. Equivalency: AFST313, Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 314, Course Title: Early Modern Britain, Course Description: The social, economic, political, religious, cultural, and intellectual history of Britain between the Reformation and the Industrial Revolution, emphasizing the rise of modern industrial society., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 319, Course Title: Britain, 1945 to the Present, Course Description: Survey of recent British history, with emphasis on de-colonization, emergence of the welfare state, new social movements and patterns of immigration, and Britain's changing relationship with Europe., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 327, Course Title: Colonial America: Encounter and Settlement, 1607 - 1763, Course Description: Encounters between European, African, and Indigenous North American peoples as well as the history of the colonies within the Atlantic world, from the late sixteenth century to the eve of the American Revolution., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 328, Course Title: Rebels in America: Revolution to Civil War, 1763 - 1865, Course Description: Issues in U.S. history from the colonial era through the Civil War, including the causes of the American Revolution; slavery; aboriginal peoples; labour, gender, and industrialization., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 329, Course Title: Heroes, Rebels, Villains, Folks: The People Who Shaped Canada, Course Description: Canadian history through the lens of individual people's lives and their social impact. Themes include race, class, gender, sexuality, indigeneity, colonialism, slavery, immigration, moral regulation, and activism., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 331, Course Title: The United States, 1865-1900: Labour, Race, Gender, and Empire, Course Description: The complicated political, economic and social history of the United States in the three decades following the Civil War., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 334, Course Title: African-American History, 1450 - 1850, Course Description: The history of African Americans from the beginnings of the African slave trade in the 15th Century through the mid-1800s and the coming of the U.S. Civil War., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 335, Course Title: African-American History, 1850 to the Present, Course Description: The history of African-Americans from the Civil War and emancipation through the present. Topics include the Jim Crow system; the Harlem Renaissance; the Civil Rights Movement; and the current economic and political status of Americans of African ancestry., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 341, Course Title: Medieval Jewish History, Course Description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 342, Course Title: Modern Jewish History, Course Description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, social and cultural transformations., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 344, Course Title: Ancient Regime France, Course Description: The political, social and/or cultural history of early modern France before the Revolution. Topics may include: the changing significance of the monarchy; the Enlightenment critique of the Catholic Church and religion; the 'pre-revolution'. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 344 or 406., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 346, Course Title: History of Modern France, Course Description: Political, social, and cultural history of France from the Revolution of 1789 to the present. France's journey toward democracy; particular focus on the changing nature of French culture and society., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 349, Course Title: Imperial Russian History, 1800 to 1917, Course Description: History of Russia from the time of Catherine the Great to the Russian Revolution with particular focus on social and cultural history., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 350, Course Title: The Soviet Union, Course Description: Political, social, and cultural history of the Soviet Union and post-Soviet successor states from 1900 to the present., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 353, Course Title: Special Topics in Middle Eastern History, Course Description: An in-depth study of one major topic in the ancient and/or modern history of the Middle East. Please consult the Department webpage for current offerings., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 355, Course Title: Nineteenth Century Germany, Course Description: The political, social, and cultural history of modern Germany during the long nineteenth century (1780s to the early twentieth century)., Credits: 	3
Course ID: HIST_V 356, Course Title: Twentieth-Century Germany, Course Description: The political, social, and cultural history of Germany in the twentieth century., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 357, Course Title: History of Mexico, Course Description: Examines themes in the last five hundred years of Mexican history, with an emphasis on the critical reading of primary sources and the use of a variety of texts that may include letters, diaries, paintings, photographs, novels, and movies., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 358, Course Title: State and Society in 20th century Cuba, Course Description: The history and historiography of 20th century Cuba, with particular attention to changing state structures and their impact on everyday life., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 359, Course Title: A History of Brazil: From Colony to Nation, Course Description: The cultural and political history of Brazil, from the earliest arrival of the Portuguese to Brazil's emergence as one of the economic powerhouses of the twenty-first century., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 362, Course Title: The Islamic Golden Age, Course Description: Political, economic, social, and cultural history of the premodern Islamic World and its global connections during the Abbasid Caliphate, with attention to the relevance of this past to our contemporary world., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 366, Course Title: Europe During the Reformation, Course Description: An examination of European history that place both the Protestant Reformation and the Catholic Reformation in the broader context of the political, social, cultural, and economic changes during the early modern era., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 368, Course Title: Europe in the 19th Century, Course Description: An investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the 20th century. Topics of particular importance are: domestic politics; the interaction of states; the formation of new states; social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization; major cultural expressions of the century., Credits: 	3
Course ID: HIST_V 373, Course Title: History of Hong Kong, Course Description: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present. Equivalency: ASIA373, Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 377, Course Title: History of Cantonese Worlds, Course Description: The history, culture, languages, and identities of the multi-faceted Cantonese worlds, in the context of Chinese history and the Cantonese diaspora. Equivalency: ASIA323 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 378, Course Title: History of Early China, Course Description: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang Empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society. Equivalency: ASIA320, Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 379, Course Title: History of Later Imperial China, Course Description: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China. Equivalency: ASIA340, Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 380, Course Title: The Making of Modern China: Nationalism, War, Revolution, Course Description: The history of China from 1800 to the present including the decline of the Qing empire, the rise of modern nationalism, foreign invasion, and China's multiple revolutions., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 381, Course Title: Imperialism and Nationalism in Southeast Asia, Course Description: The history of European imperial rule, the forms of resistance to it, and the formation of nationalist movements in Southeast Asia. The countries studied include Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Burma, and Thailand., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 382, Course Title: Post-Colonial Southeast Asia, Course Description: The history of the Japanese occupation, wars of independence, international relations of the independent nation-states, and internal armed conflicts. Special attention will be paid to the wars in Vietnam, Indonesia, and East Timor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 383, Course Title: Foundations of Sikh Traditions, Course Description: Sikh religious beliefs, practices, institutions, and thought. Emphasis on the history of the Sikh Gurus and their writings, and the larger social and cultural forces within which the tradition developed., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 386, Course Title: Korea Since 1860, Course Description: An examination of the political, economic, social, and cultural transformations of Korea since the late nineteenth century. Topics include the end of the Choson Dynasty, the history of Japanese colonial rule, the Korean war, and the two Koreas in the international system., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 387, Course Title: Voices from Medieval India, Course Description: History of medieval India explored through different stories from and about India's pre-modern past. Studies trends in society, religion, politics, and material life to reveal the dynamism of this period and to challenge simplified narratives of Hindu-Muslim confrontation., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 388, Course Title: India in the Early Modern World: Kings, Courtesans, and Saints, Course Description: History of India during the period of Mughal rule (roughly 1500-1750). Studies the role of India and the Mughals within the global dynamics of the early modern world., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 390, Course Title: Topics in History, Course Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the program website https://history.ubc.ca/courses/ for more information. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 393, Course Title: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science, Course Description: An examination of historical, conceptual, and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science. Equivalency: PHIL360, Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 397, Course Title: Environmental History of the Modern World, Course Description: Major themes in global environmental history and historiography since 1500, with a particular focus on the nineteenth through twenty-first centuries., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 398, Course Title: The History of Modern Medicine, Course Description: The history of health and disease in the modern world, focusing in particular on the emergence and history of modern biomedicine., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 399, Course Title: Theory and Practice of History, Course Description: Approaches to the history of historical inquiry, with particular attention to theoretical and methodo-logical debates among historians. Recommended for history majors. Not open to Department of History honours students., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 400, Course Title: The Practice of Oral History, Course Description: The practice, ethics, and politics of oral history. Provides research training, where students design and complete projects based on oral history interviews., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 402, Course Title: Problems in International Relations, Course Description: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 403, Course Title: Seminar in the History of International Relations, Course Description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3
Course ID: HIST_V 404, Course Title: The First World War, Course Description: WWI as a global war; cultural history and legacy; impact of imperialism on the war; military technology., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 408, Course Title: U.S. Foreign Relations from Independence to World War II, Course Description: U.S. foreign policy and international history. Examines the American rise to power and political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 409, Course Title: U.S. Foreign Relations since 1945, Course Description: U.S. foreign policy and international history. Political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 413, Course Title: Imagining the Nation: 19th- and 20th-Century Canada, Course Description: The political and intellectual history of the concept of the nation in French and English Canada, and the different forms of nationalism it inspired from the middle of the nineteenth century to the 1995 Quebec Referendum., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 415, Course Title: History of Vancouver, Course Description: Selected themes in the history of Vancouver, exploring how the study of the past illuminates or explains major debates in the city today., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 418, Course Title: The 1960s in Global Perspective, Course Description: The history of the 1960s from a transnational perspective: culture, social change, student activism, and global conflict., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 425, Course Title: War and Society, Course Description: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime as well as war; not a course in military history., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 432, Course Title: International Relations in the Twentieth Century, Course Description: History of international relations from the beginning of the twentieth century to the present. Questions of war, peace, balance of power, and the evolution of the international system in global economic, cultural, and social contexts., Credits: 	6

Course ID: HIST_V 443, Course Title: History of North American Children and Youth, Course Description: Children's history from settler days to the present. Topics include education, work and play, ideologies of childhood and adolescence, children's material and popular culture, and differences of identity based on region, class, race, and gender., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 447, Course Title: Selected Topics in United States History, Course Description: Examines in depth a significant period, theme, or topic in the history of the United States. Possible subjects include The West, the Great Depression, the Sixties, and Class, Race, and Gender., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 450, Course Title: Selected Topics in Latin American History, Course Description: A study in depth of one major topic (such as the Cuban Revolution or Peronismo) in the recent history of Latin America., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: HIST_V 464, Course Title: First Contacts in the Pacific, Course Description: An interdisciplinary history of early European contact with the Indigenous peoples of the northwest coast of North America and the Pacific Islands., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 466, Course Title: Topics in Indigenous History of Canada, Course Description: Selected interdisciplinary topics in the history of Canada's Indigenous peoples after European contact, including historical demography, economic interdependency, missionary encounters, gender relations, and interactions with colonial powers and the nation state. Recommended: HIST 302 or other background in the field. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 467, Course Title: Topics in Indigenous History of the United States, Course Description: Interdisciplinary topics in the history of the United States' Indigenous peoples from before European contact. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 468, Course Title: Topics in Comparative Indigenous History, Course Description: Comparative interdisciplinary analysis of selected topics in Indigenous history in North America and beyond. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 469, Course Title: Aboriginal Title in British Columbia: History and Legacy, Course Description: Colonial land policy, Indigenous resistance and organizing, treaties, and court decisions. Some previous knowledge of Indigenous history is strongly recommended., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 475, Course Title: Documenting Punjabi Canada, Course Description: Exploration of the history of the Punjabi Canadian community through traditional text-based methods and oral history collection. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 476, Course Title: Law and Society in the Middle Ages, Course Description: The history of law in the Middle Ages, including English common law, civil (Roman) law, and canon law, and how changes in both medieval law and society affected the development of each., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 482, Course Title: Chinese Migration, Course Description: This history of Chinese migrations from the founding of the state to the present day. Migration is used as a focus through which to examine some key themes of Chinese history; ethnicity, boundary creation, economic growth and international relations., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 484, Course Title: East Asian Military systems and warfare China, Course Description: Confucian societies are often thought of as ones in which the brush is mightier than the sword. In fact the military has been a crucial factor in East Asia, and warfare has been the engine which has driven many of the most significant changes in East Asian history. This course will look at the evolution of East Asian military systems, and at the impact of recurrent warfare on East Asia societies., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 485, Course Title: Asian Migrant Communities in Vancouver, Course Description: This course will examine the history of Asian migration to Vancouver and British Columbia, focusing on the development of local communities and provide a background in historical research methods that will enable the students to conduct research on the history of these communities., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 487, Course Title: History of Alternative and Complementary Medicine: Acupuncture to Yoga, Course Description: Alternative and complementary healing in history, including Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), yoga, meditation, and alternative drug therapies. Specific themes may vary from year to year., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 490, Course Title: Seminar for Majors in History, Course Description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 525, Course Title: Professional Development for Historians, Course Description: Offers essential skills for academic and non-academic paths in the historical profession as well as identifying alternative career possibilities for historians. Offers essential skills for academic and non-academic paths in the historical profession as well as identifying alternative career possibilities for historians. Restricted to students in the following programs: PhD in History, MA in History This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: HIST_V 699, Course Title: Ph.D. Research Seminar, Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: ILS_V 103, Course Title: Decolonization and Natural Resources, Course Description: Introduction to Indigenous People's history, cultures and experiences, and the effect on control over natural resources, drawing from local to international perspectives, with a focus on how decolonization, as an analytical lens, can transform institutions and Indigenous People's everyday lives., Credits: 	3

Course ID: INDO_V 202, Course Title: Intermediate Indonesian II, Course Description: Continuation of INDO 201. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 202 or INDO 200. Recommended pre-requisite: INDO 201. Course ID: INFO_V 304, Course Title: Memory and Identity in the Digital Age, Course Description: Personal and collective constructions of the past from collections of digital artefacts. Emphasis on history, social movements, lived experience, and public life., Credits: 	3

Course ID: INFO_V 456, Course Title: Information Policy and Society, Course Description: Develops capabilities required to assess the need for information policies in professional contexts, evaluate relevant socio-technical dimensions and envision likely implications for specific communities and practice settings. Course ID: IGEN_V 452, Course Title: Pipeline Design, Course Description: Pipeline and pipeline system design reflecting technical, regulatory, environmental, societal, professional, and economic aspects; pipeline design project. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: ISCI_V 499, Course Title: Co-Operative Work Placement IV, Course Description: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP. Prerequisite: ISCI 498. Course ID: IWME_V 506, Course Title: Water Infrastructure Capstone, Course Description: Delivery of major water infrastructure projects from policies to planning and implementation, including schedule, cost, scope, impacts, performance and risk management, indigenous participation and innovative project financing and delivery approaches. Credit will be granted for only one of: IWME 506 or CIVL 523. [3-0-1] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: RADS_V 301, Course Title: Exploring Imaging in the Twenty-First Century, Course Description: Interdisciplinary course that covers a wide range of topics regarding not only the scientific and technological basis of medical imaging, but also its origins and impact on society and the individual. Course ID: ITAL_V 395, Course Title: Special Topics Abroad, Course Description: Study of Italian literature, history, culture, or communities in an authentic context. Topics and locations may vary. Consult Department for current offerings. Recommendation: CEFR A1 Italian proficiency level., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: JAPN_V 400, Course Title: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing I, Course Description: Selected texts covering various aspects of Japanese cultural history and contemporary Japanese culture/society; emphasis on grammatical analysis and development of advanced competencies for reading and writing. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 400 or JAPN 300. Recommended pre-requisites: one of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: JAPN_V 452, Course Title: Readings in Modern Japanese Essays, Course Description: Advanced reading and analysis of scholarly texts in modern Japanese drawn from history, sociology, economics, etc. Advanced conversation, composition, and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to taking JAPN 452. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 452 or JAPN 406. Recommended pre-requisites: one of JAPN 301, JAPN 401. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: JAPN_V 459, Course Title: Topics in Japanese Language, Culture, and Society, Course Description: Advanced Japanese language course combined with analysis of various media in literary, journalistic, and popular genres drawn from history, sociology, cultural studies, etc. Practice in the use of standard reference tools prepares students for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to JAPN 459. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 459 or JAPN 419. Recommended pre-requisites: one of JAPN 301, JAPN 401; and permission from instructor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: JRNL_V 555, Course Title: International Reporting, Course Description: Restricted to students in Master of Journalism program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: KORN_V 420, Course Title: Readings in Middle and Early Modern Korean, Course Description: History and structure of the Korean language through targeted close readings in different editions of an illustrated text from the 15th and 18th centuries. Prerequisite: Non-heritage speakers should have completed KORN 410 or be taking it concurrently. Heritage and native speakers of Korean welcome., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LWS_V 550, Course Title: Professional Communications Strategies, Course Description: Communication strategies for natural resource management professionals, with an emphasis on written, oral and digital media communications in a multi-stakeholder context. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: LARC_V 522, Course Title: Landscape Architectural History, Course Description: History, principles, and theory of landscape architecture in Europe, America and Asia. Influence of cultural attitudes and societal change upon natural environments, parks, gardens, and town planning. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAST_V 415, Course Title: Seminar in Latin American Studies, Course Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the program website ( https://las.arts.ubc.ca/all-courses/ ) for further details./ Prerequisite: One of LAST 100, LAST 201, LAST 205, LAST 301, LAST 303, LAST 315. Course ID: LAW_V 200, Course Title: Indigenous Settler Legal Relations, Course Description: Critical examination of the history and legacy of colonial legal orders in Canada. This course is compulsory for students who commence their Juris Doctor degree in September 2020 or later. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 316, Course Title: International Law, Course Description: The history, sources and evidence of international law and its relation to municipal law; international personality; state jurisdiction; and treaties. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 348, Course Title: Comparative Constitutional Law, Course Description: Comparison of the constitutional history, government structure and powers, and protection of individual rights between the United States and Canada. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 352, Course Title: Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Law, Course Description: Survey of the history and present status of the legal relationships between Canada's Aboriginal peoples and the state. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 402, Course Title: The Law of Sexual Offences, Course Description: Criminal law relating to sexual offences, including non-consent, evidentiary and procedural rules, and sentencing. History of sexual offence laws and law reform movements. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 451, Course Title: Trusts, Course Description: History and nature of trusts; express, resulting, implied and constructive trusts; charitable and purpose trusts; administration of trusts; breach of trust. Credit will be only be granted for one of LAW 451 or LAW 551. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 453, Course Title: Equitable Remedies, Course Description: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 453 or LAW 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 551, Course Title: Trusts, Course Description: History and nature of trusts; express, resulting, implied and constructive trusts; charitable and purpose trusts; administration of trusts; breach of trust. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 551 or LAW 451. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: LAW_V 575, Course Title: Equitable Remedies, Course Description: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing. Credit will only be granted for one of LAW 575 or LAW 453. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MGMT_V 200, Course Title: Introduction to Management Thought and Social Responsibility, Course Description: Introduces management thought in business and organizations. Utilizes critical thinking in socially and ethically responsible decisions at a corporate and personal level. Includes managing responsibly through people, mass production, ethical and socially-responsible practices. Covers start-ups, entrepreneurs, family business, non-profit/for-profit organizations and governments in global regions. Credit will be granted for only one of MGMT 200 or MGMT 110. [3-0-0] Equivalency: MGMT 110 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: MRNE_V 502, Course Title: Special Topics, Course Description: 3 weeks. Offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists who are visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. The course will be of a specialized nature. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: MDIA_V 499, Course Title: Directed Studies, Course Description: Advanced research undertaking topics of media studies, with the agreement and under the supervision, of a faculty member with relevant expertise. Prerequisite: Restricted to BMS students with approval from the Program Chair. Course ID: MDVL_V 210, Course Title: Introduction to Medieval Studies, Course Description: A survey of the study of the medieval period in Western Europe (400-1550), integrating history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies Advisor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MDVL_V 310, Course Title: Topics in Medieval Studies, Course Description: Interdisciplinary approaches to selected topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: MDVL_V 490, Course Title: Research Seminar in Medieval Studies, Course Description: An intensive research seminar in a specific period, area, or issue integrating topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor. May include academic works or presentations, community projects, and/or digital initiatives. Prerequisite: MES 300. and permission of instructor. Recommended: Provide evidence of ACTFL Advanced High or CEFR C1.1 proficiency in Modern Standard Arabic or placement test with course instructor. Course ID: MUSC_V 128, Course Title: Music and Human Experience, Course Description: A multi-disciplinary survey of music in selected world traditions and genres, connecting it to ideas of time, evolution, history, anthropology, philosophy, and contemporary globalised culture., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MUSC_V 322, Course Title: Topics in Western Music, Course Description: Study in one major genre of Western music (e.g., The Symphony, Women in Opera, History of the Song Cycle). No musical knowledge is required. Not for credit toward the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music., Credits: 	3

Course ID: MUSC_V 327, Course Title: Cantonese Music, Course Description: A history of musical genres with Cantonese lyrics from the nineteenth century to the present. Topics include music and text relationships, major singers, major genres (narrative songs, Cantonese opera, Cantopop). Credit will be granted for only one of MUSC 327 or ASIA 335. Equivalency: ASIA 335, Credits: 	3

Course ID: MUSC_V 428, Course Title: Topics in World Music, Course Description: The history, theory, style, organology, and forms of the music of a particular culture in its aesthetic and cultural context. Students should consult the School as to which music culture will be covered in a particular year. May be repeated once for credit if different cultures are covered. Prerequisite: [MUSC328] or instructor's permission., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: MUSC_V 529, Course Title: Introduction to Ethnomusicology, Course Description: Preliminary studies in the discipline of ethnomusicology, with an emphasis on history and orientations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: MUSC_V 537, Course Title: Seminar in the Literature of Opera, Course Description: Special topics related to the bibliography, history, repertoire and pedagogy of operatic music. Prerequisite: [MUSC221, MUSC301, MUSC454, MUSC455, MUSC520] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: MUSC_V 547, Course Title: Seminar in the Literature of Song, Course Description: Special topics related to the bibliography, history, repertoire and pedagogy of song. Prerequisite: [MUSC221, MUSC301, MUSC365, MUSC465, MUSC520] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: NRES_V 443, Course Title: Remote Sensing for Ecosystem Management, Course Description: Basic biological concepts related to interpretation of remote sensing data for land management, including the use of films and filters, and interpretation of air photographs, and other imagery. Credit will be granted for only one of NRES 443 or FRST 443. [2-2-0] Equivalency: FRST 443, GEOS 375 Subscribe to NRES_V Course Descriptions Introduction Courses by Subject Courses by Faculty/School/College UBC Academic Calendar Vancouver Campus 2016 1874 East Mall Vancouver,                  BC                  Canada V6T 1Z1 The University of British Columbia About UBC Contact UBC About the University News Events Careers Make a Gift Search UBC.ca UBC Campuses Vancouver Campus Okanagan Campus UBC Sites Robson Square Centre for Digital Media Faculty of Medicine Across BC Emergency Procedures | Terms of Use | UBC Copyright | Accessibility to top Calendar Sections Home Dates and Deadlines Academic Year Admissions Fees Establishment and Constitution Campus-wide Policies and Regulations Services, Facilities, and Organizations Research Units, Centres, and Institutes UBC Library Faculties, Colleges, and Schools Alternative Study Options Course Descriptions Emeriti Staff Enrolment Statistics 2023/24 Calendar History Calendar Archive Contact Us UBC Crest The official logo of the University of British Columbia. Course ID: NSCI_V 499, Course Title: Cooperative Work Placement IV, Course Description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in the Summer Session after 4th year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Neuroscience. Prerequisite: NSCI 498. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: NORD_V 340, Course Title: Sámi Histories and Cultures, Course Description: Cultural history of the Sámi peoples, the Indigenous peoples of northern Norway, Sweden, Finland and Russias Kola Peninsula. Focus on traditional culture, colonization, and decolonization., Credits: 	3

Course ID: NORD_V 415, Course Title: The World of the Sagas, Course Description: Explore the medieval and early modern world of the Nordic region through the Icelandic sagas and their literary, cultural, and historical context. Credit will be granted for only one of SCAN 415 or NORD 415. Course ID: PATH_V 375, Course Title: Introduction to Human Pathology, Course Description: Causes, natural history and pathophysiology of common disease processes. Prerequisite: 6 credits each first year BIOL and CHEM, Credits: 	3

Course ID: PERS_V 300, Course Title: Intermediate-High Persian I, Course Description: Graded reading, writing, exposure to textual history, newspaper reading, and translation. Cultural materials presented as appropriate. Recommended pre-requisites: PERS 201 or Persian heritage speakers with basic reading/writing skills (no more than Grade 6 formal education in Iran)., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PERS_V 401, Course Title: Contemporary Iranian Cinema for Advanced Speakers of Persian, Course Description: Iranian cultural norms, and sociopolitical information about Iranian society and history, as conveyed through Iranian cinema. Emphasis on speaking, writing, and vocabulary development of Persian language. Recommended pre-requisites: PERS 300, or native or proficient heritage speaker of Persian with permission of the instructor., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PERS_V 451, Course Title: Persian through Shahnameh for Advanced Speakers of Persian, Course Description: Persian through Shahnameh, with a focus on speaking, reading, writing and vocabulary development. Emphasis on Iranian cultural norms, mentalities and values. Recommended pre-requisite: PERS 300 or native or proficient heritage speaker of Persian, with permission of the instructor. Course ID: PHRM_V 321, Course Title: Travel Health, Course Description: Providing a consultative service to patients based on patient medical and travel history. Recommending and administering vaccinations according to guidelines. Making recommendations regarding oral medications needed for safe travel. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHRM_V 524, Course Title: Pharmacy Leadership Seminar, Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: PHIL_V 360, Course Title: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science, Course Description: An examination of historical, conceptual and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science. Equivalency: HIST393, Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHIL_V 419, Course Title: Philosophy of History, Course Description: Concepts of history and historical explanation, historical progress, purpose, necessity, law and causation. Hegel, Marx, Vico, Spengler, Pareto, Collingwood, Croce, and Toynbee, as well as contemporary figures. Students will be expected to have an adequate knowledge of ancient or modern history., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHIL_V 461, Course Title: Philosophy of Social Science, Course Description: Topics in the philosophy of science of special concern to the social sciences: the problem of objectivity, the use of models and evidence, causation and causal reasoning, formal methods, the status of social kinds and norms, scientific explanation, laws. Prerequisite: 9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PHTH_V 581, Course Title: Evidence and Theory in Musculoskeletal Physical Therapy, Course Description: Restricted to students in the Graduate Certificate in Orthopaedic Musculoskeletal Physical Therapy program. Prerequisite: RHSC 501. Corequisite: PHTH 580. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: PLNT_V 575, Course Title: Indigenous Ecologies, Course Description: Application of Indigenous worldviews and knowledges to ecology. Colonial history of modern ecology, foundations and examples of Indigenous ecologies, restoration applying multiple worldviews, and Indigenized, culturally appropriate ecological research and decision-making processes. Credit will only be granted for only one of APBI 475, FRST 475, PLNT 575 or FRST 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: POLS_V 426, Course Title: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film (in English), Course Description: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and film. Course ID: POLI_V 327, Course Title: European Integration, Course Description: Post-1945 integration of Europe, comparison of national politics and attitudes to integration, and the history and institutions of the European Union. Prerequisite: All of POLI 100, POLI 101, POLI 240. Or third-year standing or higher., Credits: 	3

Course ID: POLI_V 443, Course Title: Modern Western Political Thought, Course Description: Seminar: Texts in the history of modern Western political thought, such as works by Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Karl Marx, Alexis de Tocqueville, John Stuart Mill, Friedrich Nietzsche, Max Weber, and Sigmund Freud. Restricted to students in fourth-year standing or higher., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: PORT_V 405, Course Title: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Culture (in English), Course Description: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 405 or RMST 460. Recommended pre-requisite: Second-year standing or higher. Course ID: PSYC_V 300, Course Title: Abnormal Psychology, Course Description: The definition, history, and scope of abnormal behaviour; emphasis on the psychological factors that control its origins, maintenance, and modification. Restricted to students with second-year standing or higher. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and one of PSYC 216, 217, or 227., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PSYC_V 312, Course Title: History of Psychology, Course Description: The principal trends of psychological explanation and events in the history of psychology from the earliest times to the present. Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and one of PSYC 216, 217, or 277. Restricted to Psychology Major or Psychology Honours students., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PPGA_V 542, Course Title: Science, Technology, and Public Policy, Course Description: Role and influence of science and technology in society, and its relationship to public policy development including: history and economics of technological change. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PUNJ_V 457, Course Title: Punjabi Theatre, Course Description: Punjabi-language theatre, with emphasis on Canadian forms. Reading, writing, and performance of plays; examination of history of Punjabi theatre. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300., Credits: 	3

Course ID: PUNJ_V 475, Course Title: Oral Histories in Punjabi, Course Description: Develops students' oral expression and listening comprehension in Punjabi through Community Based Learning. Students engage in oral history collection in the Punjabi-speaking community and develop short video or sound projects. Analytical reading and writing required. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300. Course ID: RHSC_V 502, Course Title: Rehabilitation Theory, Course Description: The history, evolution and analysis of conceptual systems underlying practice in occupational therapy and physical therapy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RGLA_V 471, Course Title: Advanced Seminar in Religion and Literature, Course Description: Application of critical methods to one or more major authors. Course ID: RELG_V 207, Course Title: Classical Islam, Course Description: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Islamic societies from 700-1500; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RELG_V 208, Course Title: Modern Islam, Course Description: The history and culture, values, and socio-political movements of the Islamic world from 1500 to the modern day; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in modern Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RELG_V 211, Course Title: History of Christianity II (15th C. C.E. - present), Course Description: The history of Christianity from the Reformation to the present day. Provides an historical overview of Christian thought and its institutions and significant people during the rise of the Reformation in various locales of Europe and beyond (Germany, France, Great Britain, Switzerland, and Scandinavia)., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RELG_V 312, Course Title: Jews and Judaism in Canada, Course Description: The history of the Jewish community in Canada, from New France to the present. Emphasis on the relationship between immigration and religious transformation, Jewish-Christian relations, the development of community structures., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RELG_V 331, Course Title: Medieval Jewish History, Course Description: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RELG_V 332, Course Title: Modern Jewish History, Course Description: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present, with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, and social and cultural transformations., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RELG_V 366, Course Title: Buddhism in China, Course Description: History, thought and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century. Equivalency: ASIA382, Credits: 	3

Course ID: RES_V 501, Course Title: Development of Environmental Thought, Course Description: History and philosophy of Western environmental thought; changes in concepts of human nature and external nature over time; critiques of modern industrial society. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RES_V 506, Course Title: Human Dimensions of Conservation, Course Description: History of wilderness and protected areas; ecological dynamics underpinning biodiversity; evaluating the success of protected areas and ecological dynamics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RMST_V 305, Course Title: Introduction to Romance Language Cinema, Course Description: Overview of the history, aesthetics and characteristics of films in French, Italian, Spanish, and/or Portuguese. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 234 or RMST 305., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RMST_V 325, Course Title: French Cultural Identities, Course Description: Aspects of French culture through a set of key concepts that weave across French history, politics, and social structures. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 325 or FREN 380., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RMST_V 395, Course Title: Special Topics Abroad, Course Description: Study of Romance language literature, history, culture, or communities in an authentic context. Topics and locations may vary. Consult Department for current offerings., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: RMST_V 402, Course Title: Visions of Nature and the Environment in the Romance World, Course Description: History, literature and philosophy of anthropization and ecology in the Romance world. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SANS_V 300, Course Title: Introductory Sanskrit, Course Description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302., Credits: 	6

Course ID: SANS_V 301, Course Title: Introductory Sanskrit I, Course Description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPPH_V 525, Course Title: Issues and Concepts in Public Health, Course Description: History of public health research and practice; occupational and environmental health; health services and systems; social and lifecourse determinants of health; and population health and emerging trends. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SCIE_V 599, Course Title: Co-operative Work Placement IV, Course Description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Prerequisite: SCIE 598. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: STS_V 501, Course Title: Proseminar in Science and Technology Studies, Course Description: Classic work in the history, philosophy, rhetoric, and sociology of science, and the development of a unified science and technology studies. Required for all students in the STS Program. This course is co-taught. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SLAV_V 307, Course Title: Literature and Film in Eastern Europe, Course Description: Films and translated literature by Slavic writers with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature. Course ID: SOWK_V 325, Course Title: Indigenous Peoples and Critical Social Work Analysis, Course Description: Contemporary social issues facing Indigenous peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Settler-Canadian/Indigenous relations; the impact of Settler-Canadian institutions upon Indigenous peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 325 or 425. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SOCI_V 383, Course Title: Sociological Methods: Historical Research, Course Description: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217., Credits: 	3

Course ID: SPAN_V 395, Course Title: Special Topics Abroad, Course Description: Study of Hispanic literature, history, culture, or communities in an authentic context. Topics and locations may vary. Consult Department for current offerings. Recommendation: CEFR A2 Spanish proficiency level, Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: SPAN_V 403, Course Title: History of the Spanish Language, Course Description: Major features of the development of the Spanish language, from its origins to the present. Includes the history of Spanish phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and dialectology. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish., Credits: 	3

Course ID: RGST_V 499, Course Title: Honours Thesis, Course Description: Undergraduate thesis on a subject in the study of religion. Restricted to students admitted to the Honours Program in the Study of Religion. Course ID: SURG_V 560, Course Title: Global Surgical Care Field Practicum, Course Description: Course with a four to eight week on-site field placement. Proposal development, implementation and high-level written report of a surgical care field practicum in an underserved location globally, producing practical on-the-ground skills. Prerequisite: All of SURG 510, SURG 512, SURG 514, SURG 516. Corequisite: SURG 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: SPE_V 505, Course Title: Technology Commercialization for the Manufacturing Industries, Course Description: Creation and leadership of new ventures for scale-up and commercialization of manufacturing processes, with a special emphasis on the chemical and ancillary industries. Includes assessment of manufacturing processes; techno-economic analyses; scaling up and de-risking processes; intellectual property; market penetration that are specific to the manufacturing sector. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: THTR_V 210, Course Title: Drama: Forms and Ideas I, Course Description: The Anatomy of Drama: Its history, aesthetic principles, performative potential., Credits: 	3
Course ID: THTR_V 320, Course Title: History of Theatre I, Course Description: Core concepts in world theatre history and the development of theatre prior to the nineteenth century., Credits: 	3
Course ID: THTR_V 420, Course Title: History of Theatre II, Course Description: Key movements in world theatre history from the nineteenth century to the present. Prerequisite: THTR 320., Credits: 	3

Course ID: THTR_V 440, Course Title: Topics in Theatre, Course Description: An examination in depth of a selected area of theatre history, theory or practice. Topics will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ. Prerequisite: 6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above., Credits: 	3-6

Course ID: THTR_V 521, Course Title: Styles in Directing, Course Description: An advanced course in directing; detailed study of the major styles in the history of production. Prerequisite: [THTR520] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

Course ID: THFL_V 599, Course Title: Production, Course Description: Assigned projects in Theatre and Film design and production. Restricted to students in the MFA THTR and MFA FIPR programs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: VISA_V 280, Course Title: Contemporary Art: Ideas as Practice II, Course Description: Development and history of contemporary art practice, with a focus on how artists realize and exchange ideas. Intended for second year BFA VISA students. Prerequisite: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 183., Credits: 	3

Course ID: VISA_V 330, Course Title: Intermediate Painting I, Course Description: Development of techniques and personal style in relation to ideas. History and contemporary issues in painting will be introduced to assist students in conceptualizing their painting practice. Prerequisite: One of VISA 230, VISA 282, FINA 282., Credits: 	3

Course ID: VISA_V 375, Course Title: Artists in Society, Course Description: Exploring artistic practice through community-engaged partnerships and critical study. Prerequisite: Restricted to students with at least third-year standing, majoring in Visual Art or Art History. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

Course ID: VISA_V 590, Course Title: Directed Studies in Visual Art, Course Description: Tutorial work in visual arts and theory arranged by permission with an individual faculty member. Not available to students enrolled in the M.F.A. program in Visual Arts. The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Course ID: WOOD_V 576, Course Title: Advanced Wood Mechanics, Course Description: Analysis and design of structural wood products. Effect of material structure and variability on performance of wood products. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. prompt: Tell me about Human Nutrition courses.
completion: Course ID: FNH_V 160, Course Title: Integrated Physiology for Human Nutrition I, Course Description: Basic principles in human physiology, including function of the nervous, endocrine, musculoskeletal and digestive systems, integration across systems, maintenance of homeostasis, and application to human nutrition. Prerequisite: One of CHEM 11, CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, ATPH 12, BIOL 12, BIOL 111. FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Human Nutrition courses.
completion: Course ID: FNH_V 161, Course Title: Integrated Physiology for Human Nutrition II, Course Description: Basic principles in human physiology, including function of the cardiovascular, immune, respiratory, urinary and reproductive systems, integration across systems, maintenance of homeostasis, and application to human nutrition. Prerequisite: FNH 160. FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Human Nutrition courses.
completion: Course ID: FNH_V 250, Course Title: Nutrition Concepts and Controversies, Course Description: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of FNH 160, FNH 161 or (b) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (c) all of KIN 131, KIN 132. At least second-year standing required., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Human Nutrition courses.
completion: Course ID: HUNU_V 500, Course Title: Research Methods in Human Nutrition, Course Description: Experimental design, methods of survey research, nutritional epidemiology, clinical research, and laboratory animal research. Issues such as animal models, ethics in animal and human research, statistical methods, and preparation of written reports and manuscripts, etc., will be addressed. Required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Human Nutrition. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Indigenous Land Stewardship courses.
completion: Course ID: ILS_V 400, Course Title: Policy Building and Processes, Course Description: Policy theory and practice in the Indigenous land stewardship context. Topics include developing and influencing policy and the drivers of policy change. Prerequisite: ILS 203., Credits: 	3
Course ID: INDO_V 100, Course Title: Introductory Indonesian I, Course Description: Spoken and written Indonesian. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 100 or INDO 102., Credits: 	3

Course ID: INDO_V 102, Course Title: Introductory Indonesian, Course Description: Spoken and written Indonesian. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of INDO 100/101 or INDO 102., Credits: 	6

Course ID: INDO_V 200, Course Title: Intermediate Indonesian, Course Description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Indonesian literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of INDO 201/202 or INDO 200. Recommended pre-requisites: one of INDO 101, INDO 102., Credits: 	6

Course ID: INDO_V 201, Course Title: Intermediate Indonesian I, Course Description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Indonesian literature. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 201 or INDO 200. Recommended pre-requisite: INDO 101., Credits: 	3

prompt: Tell me about Integrated Engineering courses.

completion: Course ID: IGEN_V 201, Course Title: Integrated Technical Communication, Course Description: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material. completion: Course ID: IGEN_V 230, Course Title: Introduction to Engineering Design, Course Description: Introduction to engineering design methods, problem solving, working individually and in teams, and methods of communication of results. Engineering design projects will be assigned. Restricted to students in the second year of the Integrated Engineering program. [1-4-0;1-4-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

completion: Course ID: IGEN_V 330, Course Title: Intermediate Engineering Design, Course Description: Intermediate level engineering design projects involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program. [1-4;1-4] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading., Credits: 	6

completion: Course ID: IGEN_V 430, Course Title: Advanced Engineering Design Projects, Course Description: Projects involving all material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering Program.
